Comparatorå¯¹äºæ¯ä¸ª exprï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç›´æ¥æšä¸¾ä¸¤ä¸ªè¾“å…¥çš„ 4 ç§å–å€¼ï¼ˆx=0/1, y=0/1ï¼‰ï¼Œå¹¶è®¡ç®—è¡¨è¾¾å¼çš„ç»“æœã€‚ å› æ­¤å¯¹äºæ¯æ¡ IFFY è¯­å¥ï¼š 1a b expr r å®ƒçš„æ•ˆæœç­‰ä»·äºä¸è¶…è¿‡ 4 æ¡ç®€å•è§„åˆ™ï¼š å¦‚æœ word1 çš„ç¬¬ $a$ ä½ç­‰äº $u$ ä¸” word2 çš„ç¬¬ $b$ ä½ç­‰äº $v$ï¼Œåˆ™ç«‹å³è¿”å› $r$ æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½çš„ $(a, u, b, v)$ ç»„åˆæ•°é‡ä¸ºï¼š $$k 	imes 2 	imes k 	imes 2 = 4k^2$$ ä¸€æ—¦æŸä¸ª $(a, u, b, v)$ å·²ç»è¢«æ›´æ—©çš„è¯­å¥è¦†ç›–ï¼Œåœ¨æ­¤ä¹‹åå‡ºç°çš„ç›¸åŒç»„åˆå°±å¯ä»¥è¢«å¿½ç•¥ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™äº›è¾“å…¥å¯¹ $(x, y)$ å·²ç»è¿”å›è¿‡ç»“æœäº†ã€‚ å› æ­¤ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åªéœ€è¦å¤„ç†ä¸è¶…è¿‡ $4k^2$ æ¡æœ‰æ•ˆè§„åˆ™ã€‚å¯¹äºæ¯æ¡è§„åˆ™ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨ $O(2^{2k})$ çš„æ—¶é—´å†…ï¼Œæšä¸¾æ‰€æœ‰æ»¡è¶³ $	ext{bit}_a(word1) = u \quad 	ext{ä¸”} \quad 	ext{bit}_b(word2) = v$ çš„ (word1, word2) å¯¹ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸ºå®ƒä»¬èµ‹è¿”å›å€¼ $r$ã€‚ å¯¹äºç­”æ¡ˆç»Ÿè®¡ï¼š è‡ªåæ€§è¿ä¾‹æ•°: æš´åŠ›æšä¸¾æ‰€æœ‰å•è¯ $x$ï¼Œç»Ÿè®¡ï¼š$f(x, x) = 1$ çš„æ¬¡æ•°ã€‚ å¯¹ç§°æ€§è¿ä¾‹æ•°: æš´åŠ›æšä¸¾æ‰€æœ‰ $(x, y)$ å¯¹ï¼Œç»Ÿè®¡ï¼š$f(x, y) = 1 \quad 	ext{ä¸”} \quad f(y, x) = 1$ çš„æ¬¡æ•°ã€‚ ä¼ é€’æ€§è¿ä¾‹æ•°: æšä¸¾æ‰€æœ‰ $(x, y)$ï¼Œå¦‚æœ $f(x, y) = 1$ï¼Œåˆ™å¯¹äºæ‰€æœ‰æ»¡è¶³ $f(y, z) = 1$ çš„ $z$ï¼Œæ£€æŸ¥æ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨ï¼š$f(x, z) 
eq 1$çš„æƒ…å†µã€‚ è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨ bitset å­˜å‚¨æ¯ä¸€è¡Œçš„ $f$ å€¼é›†åˆï¼Œåˆ©ç”¨é›†åˆçš„æŒ‰ä½è¿ç®—å¯ä»¥åœ¨ï¼š$O\left( rac{2^k}{w}ight)$ æ—¶é—´å†…å®Œæˆä¸€æ¬¡æŒ‰è¡Œç»Ÿè®¡ æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š è§£æä¸æ±‚å€¼è¡¨è¾¾å¼ï¼šæ¯æ¡è¡¨è¾¾å¼åªéœ€è®¡ç®— 4 ç§ $(x, y)$ è¾“å…¥ï¼Œå¤æ‚åº¦ï¼š$O\left(\sum |expr|ight)$ å¡«å…… $f$ è¡¨ï¼šæœ€å¤š $4k^2$ æ¡æœ‰æ•ˆè§„åˆ™ï¼Œæ¯æ¡è§„åˆ™ $O(2^{2k})$ â†’ $O\left(k^2 \cdot 2^{2k}ight)$ æ£€æŸ¥æ€§è´¨ï¼š è‡ªåã€å¯¹ç§°ï¼š$O(2^{2k})$ ä¼ é€’ï¼ˆbitset ä¼˜åŒ–ï¼‰ï¼š$O\left( rac{2^{3k}}{w}ight)$ æ€»æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ä¸ºï¼š $$O\left( \sum |expr| + k^2 \cdot 2^{2k} +  rac{2^{3k}}{w} ight)$$  int K = 1024;int priority(char c) { if (c == '(') return -1; if (c == '!') return 5; if (c == '=') return 4; if (c == '&') return 3; if (c == '|') return 2; if (c == '^') return 1; return 10;}void solve() { int n = read(), k = read(); vector vis(k, vector(k, array<array<int, 2>, 2>{})); vector f(1 << k, bitset<K>{}); vector vf(1 << k, bitset<K>{}); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { int a = read(), b = read(); string expr; cin >> expr; int r = read(); a--, b--; vector<char> stk; string suf; for (auto c : expr) { if (c == 'x' or c == 'y' or c == '0' or c == '1') { stk.eb(c); } else if (c == '(') { stk.eb(c); } else if (c == ')') { while (stk.back() != '(') { suf += stk.back(); stk.pop_back(); } stk.pop_back(); } else { while (!stk.empty() and priority(c) < priority(stk.back())) { suf += stk.back(); stk.pop_back(); } stk.eb(c); } } while (!stk.empty()) { suf += stk.back(); stk.pop_back(); } // cerr << suf << '
'; for (int x : {0, 1}) { for (int y : {0, 1}) { if (vis[a][b][x][y]) continue; vector<int> v; for (auto c : suf) { if (c == '0') { v.push_back(0); } else if (c == '1') { v.push_back(1); } else if (c == 'x') { v.push_back(x); } else if (c == 'y') { v.push_back(y); } else if (c == '!') { v.back() ^= 1; } else { int a = v.back(); v.pop_back(); int b = v.back(); v.pop_back(); if (c == '=') { v.push_back(a == b); } else if (c == '&') { v.push_back(a & b); } else if (c == '|') { v.push_back(a | b); } else if (c == '^') { v.push_back(a ^ b); } } } // assert(v.size() == 1); if (v[0]) { vis[a][b][x][y] = 1; for (int i = 0; i < (1 << k); i++) { if (((i >> a) & 1) == x) { for (int j = 0; j < (1 << k); j++) { if (((j >> b) & 1) == y and !vf[i][j]) { f[i][j] = r; vf[i][j] = 1; } } } } } } } } int r = read(); for (int i = 0; i < (1 << k); i++) { for (int j = 0; j < (1 << k); j++) { if (!vf[i][j]) { vf[i][j] = 1; f[i][j] = r; } } } int ans1 = 0, ans2 = 0, ans3 = 0; for (int x = 0; x < (1 << k); x++) { if (f[x][x]) ans1++; for (int y = 0; y < (1 << k); y++) { if (f[x][y] and f[y][x]) { ans2++; } if (f[x][y]) { ans3 += (f[y] & ~f[x]).count(); } } } cout << ans1 << ' ' << ans2 << ' ' << ans3 << '
';} M. Training, Round 2è®¾ $f(j)$ è¡¨ç¤ºåŠ å®ç° $j$ æ¬¡æ—¶ï¼Œæ€ç»´èƒ½åŠ›çš„å¯è¡Œå–å€¼é›†åˆã€‚åˆå§‹ $f(0) = {t_0}$ï¼Œå…¶ä½™ä¸ºç©ºã€‚æŒ‰é¢˜ç›®é¡ºåºä¾æ¬¡å¤„ç†ï¼Œæ¯é“é¢˜å¯¹åº”å®ç°åŒºé—´ä¸æ€ç»´åŒºé—´çš„ä¸€ä¸ªçŸ©å½¢é™åˆ¶ã€‚ å¯¹äºæ¯ä¸ª $j$ï¼Œå°† $f(j)$ ä¸è¯¥çŸ©å½¢ç›¸äº¤ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°å¯è¡Œå­é›† $S$ã€‚å¯¹ $S$ ä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸ªå…ƒç´ ï¼Œæœ‰ä¸¤ç§æ‰©å±•ï¼š å°†å…¶åŠ å…¥ $f(j+1)$ï¼ˆå¯¹åº”åŠ å®ç°ï¼‰ï¼› å°†å…¶åŠ ä¸€åä»ç•™åœ¨ $f(j)$ï¼ˆå¯¹åº”åŠ æ€ç»´ï¼‰ã€‚ ç”±äºå¯è¡Œé›†åˆåœ¨ä¸€ç»´ä¸Šä¿æŒè¿ç»­æ€§ï¼Œ$f(j)$ å¯ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªåŒºé—´è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨è½¬ç§»æ—¶å–äº¤æˆ–å¹¶ã€‚ æœ€ç»ˆç­”æ¡ˆä¸ºæ‰€æœ‰ $j$ ä¸­ $\max(j + 	ext{max}(f(j)) - t_0)$ï¼Œæ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ $O(n^2)$ã€‚ 1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829303132333435363738void solve() { int n = read(); int i0 = read(); int t0 = read(); vector<int> l(n + 1), r(n + 1, -1); l[0] = r[0] = t0; for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { int il = read(), ir = read(); int tl = read(), tr = read(); for (int j = i; j >= 0; j--) { if (i0 + j < il or i0 + j > ir) continue; int L = max(l[j], tl); int R = min(r[j], tr); if (L > R) continue; r[j] = max(r[j], R + 1); if (r[j + 1] < l[j + 1]) { l[j + 1] = L; r[j + 1] = R; } else { l[j + 1] = min(l[j + 1], L); r[j + 1] = max(r[j + 1], R); } } } int ans = 0; for (int j = 0; j <= n; j++) { if (l[j] <= r[j]) { ans = max(ans, j + r[j] - t0); } } cout << ans << '
';} I. Not Another Constructive!è®¾ $f(i, N, C)$ è¡¨ç¤ºå¤„ç†å‰ $i$ ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦æ—¶ï¼Œå·²æœ‰ $N$ ä¸ª Nï¼Œæœªæ¥è¿˜æœ‰ $C$ ä¸ª Cï¼Œå¯è¡Œçš„ "NAC" å­åºåˆ—æ•°é‡é›†åˆã€‚åˆå§‹ $f(0, 0, C) = {0}$ å¯¹æ‰€æœ‰ $C$ æˆç«‹ï¼Œå…¶ä½™ä¸ºç©ºã€‚ ä¾æ¬¡å¤„ç†æ¯ä¸ªä½ç½®ï¼Œæ ¹æ®å­—ç¬¦ç§ç±»è¿›è¡Œè½¬ç§»ï¼š è‹¥ä¸º 'N'ï¼Œåˆ™è½¬ç§»åˆ° $(N+1, C)$ï¼› è‹¥ä¸º 'A'ï¼Œåˆ™ NAC æ•°æ•´ä½“å¢åŠ  $N 	imes C$ï¼ˆé›†åˆæ•´ä½“å·¦ç§»è¯¥å€¼ï¼‰ï¼› è‹¥ä¸º 'C'ï¼Œåˆ™è½¬ç§»åˆ° $(N, C-1)$ï¼› å…¶å®ƒå­—ç¬¦ä¿æŒçŠ¶æ€ä¸å˜ã€‚ ç”±äº NAC æ•°é›†åˆå¯å‹ä¸ºé•¿åº¦ $K+1$ çš„å¸ƒå°”æ•°ç»„ï¼Œèƒ½ç”¨ bitset åŠ é€Ÿã€‚ æœ«å°¾æ£€æŸ¥ $f(n, N, 0)$ ä¸­æ˜¯å¦åŒ…å«ç›®æ ‡ $k$ï¼›è‹¥å­˜åœ¨åˆ™è‡ªå³å‘å·¦å›æº¯ï¼Œæ ¹æ®å¯è¡Œæ€§ä¾æ¬¡ç¡®å®šæ¯ä¸ª â€˜?â€™ çš„å–å€¼ï¼Œæ„é€ å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªæ»¡è¶³æ¡ä»¶çš„ä¸²ã€‚ æ€»çŠ¶æ€æ•° $O(n^3)$ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªçŠ¶æ€æ›´æ–°å¤æ‚åº¦ $O(K / w)$ï¼ˆ$w$ ä¸ºå­—é•¿ï¼‰ï¼Œåœ¨ $n \le 40, K \le 2500$ æ—¶å¯è¡Œã€‚ 12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940414243444546474849505152535455565758596061626364656667686970717273const int K = 2500;void solve() { int n = read(); int k = read(); string s; cin >> s; vector dp(n + 1, vector(n + 1, vector(n + 1, bitset<K + 1>{}))); for (int i = 0; i <= n; i++) { dp[0][0][i][0] = 1; } for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { if (s[i] == '?' or s[i] == 'N') { for (int N = 0; N <= i; N++) { for (int C = 0; C <= n - i; C++) { dp[i + 1][N + 1][C] |= dp[i][N][C]; } } } if (s[i] == '?' or s[i] == 'A') { for (int N = 0; N <= i; N++) { for (int C = 0; C <= n - i; C++) { dp[i + 1][N][C] |= dp[i][N][C] << (N * C); } } } if (s[i] == '?' or s[i] == 'C') { for (int N = 0; N <= i; N++) { for (int C = 1; C <= n - i; C++) { dp[i + 1][N][C - 1] |= dp[i][N][C]; } } } if (s[i] == '?' or (s[i] != 'N' and s[i] != 'A' and s[i] != 'C')) { for (int N = 0; N <= i; N++) { for (int C = 0; C <= n - i; C++) { dp[i + 1][N][C] |= dp[i][N][C]; } } } } int N = -1; for (int i = 0; i <= n; i++) { if (dp[n][i][0][k]) { N = i; } } if (N == -1) { cout << "-1
"; return; } int C = 0; for (int i = n - 1; i >= 0; i--) { if ((s[i] == '?' or s[i] == 'N') and N > 0 and dp[i][N - 1][C][k]) { s[i] = 'N'; N--; } else if ((s[i] == '?' or s[i] == 'A') and k >= N * C and dp[i][N][C][k - N * C]) { s[i] = 'A'; k -= N * C; } else if ((s[i] == '?' or s[i] == 'C') and dp[i][N][C + 1][k]) { s[i] = 'C'; C++; } else if (s[i] == '?') { s[i] = 'Z'; } } cout << s << '
';} F. Magic Beanwork å‡½æ•°ï¼šæ‰§è¡Œä¸€æ¬¡æ—‹è½¬ æŠŠå½“å‰æ“ä½œè®°å½•åˆ° ansï¼ˆå¦‚ "o3"ï¼‰ã€‚ å¦‚æœæ˜¯ å¤–å›´åœˆ (x < 3)ï¼š ç”¨ std::rotate å®ç°é¡ºæ—¶é’ˆæ—‹è½¬ k æ ¼ã€‚ æ³¨æ„ rotate çš„å‚æ•°æ˜¯ â€œæŠŠæœ€å k ä¸ªå…ƒç´ ç§»åˆ°æœ€å‰é¢â€ æ¥æ¨¡æ‹Ÿé¡ºæ—¶é’ˆè½¬ã€‚ å¦‚æœæ˜¯ ä¸­é—´åœˆ (x == 3)ï¼š ä¸­å¿ƒåœˆæ—‹è½¬çš„æ•ˆæœæ˜¯â€œ3 æ¡è½¨é“ä¹‹é—´ï¼Œäº¤æ¢æŸäº›ä½ç½®çš„ç å­â€ã€‚ è¿™æ®µä»£ç æŠŠæ¯ä¸ªâ€œå¯¹åº”åˆ—â€çš„ç å­å–å‡ºæ¥ï¼ˆæ¯ä¸ªåˆ—æœ‰æ¥è‡ªä¸‰ä¸ªåœˆçš„ç å­ï¼‰ï¼Œç„¶åé¡ºæ—¶é’ˆæ—‹è½¬ k æ ¼ï¼Œå†æ”¾å›å»ã€‚ ä¸»è¿˜åŸå¾ªç¯: é¡ºç€æ¯ä¸€åœˆå»æ‰¾ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªä¸å¯¹é¢œè‰²çš„ç å­ æŠŠå®ƒé€šè¿‡ä¸€äº›æ—‹è½¬ï¼ˆå¤–å›´åœˆ + ä¸­å¿ƒåœˆï¼‰æ”¾å›è‡ªå·±åº”è¯¥çš„åœˆ åŒæ—¶ä¸ä¼šç ´åå·²ç»å¥½çš„éƒ¨åˆ† å…·ä½“æ­¥éª¤ï¼š éå†ä¸‰æ¡åœˆï¼ˆi=0..2ï¼‰ï¼Œå†éå†æ¯åœˆçš„æ¯ä¸ªä½ç½®ï¼ˆj=0..9ï¼‰ å¦‚æœè¿™ä¸ªä½ç½®çš„é¢œè‰²æ­£ç¡®ï¼ˆs[i][j] == t[i]ï¼‰ï¼Œè·³è¿‡ å¦åˆ™ï¼Œæ‰§è¡Œä¸€ç³»åˆ—æ“ä½œï¼š å¦‚æœä¸åœ¨åœˆçš„ 0 å·ä½ç½®ï¼Œå°±å…ˆæ—‹è½¬è¯¥åœˆï¼ŒæŠŠé”™ç å­ç§»åˆ°ä½ç½® 0ã€‚ i1 = t.find(s[i][0]) æ‰¾å‡ºè¿™ä¸ªé”™ç å­åº”è¯¥å±äºå“ªä¸€åœˆï¼ˆçœ‹å®ƒçš„é¢œè‰²ï¼‰ã€‚ åœ¨ i1 è¿™ä¸ªåœˆä¸­ï¼Œæ‰¾ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªè¿˜æ²¡å¯¹é½çš„ä½ç½® j1ã€‚ å¦‚æœ j1 != 3ï¼ˆç›®æ ‡æ’å…¥ä½ç½®ä¸æ˜¯ 3 å·ä½ç½®ï¼‰ï¼Œå°±æŠŠ i1 åœˆè½¬ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼ŒæŠŠå®ƒç©ºå‡ºæ¥ã€‚ ç”¨ä¸­å¿ƒåœˆæ—‹è½¬ï¼ŒæŠŠç å­æ¢åˆ°æ­£ç¡®çš„åœˆä¸Šå»ã€‚ å†è°ƒæ•´å¤–å›´åœˆã€ä¸­å¿ƒåœˆçš„é¡ºåºï¼Œä¿è¯æ•´ä½“æ­£ç¡®æ€§ã€‚ 12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940414243444546474849505152void solve() { string s[3]; for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) cin >> s[i]; const string t = "ogrc"; vector<string> ans; auto work = [&](int x, int k) { ans.eb(t.substr(x, 1) + char(k + '0')); if (x < 3) { rotate(s[x].begin(), s[x].end() - k, s[x].end()); } else { for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) { string u; for (int j = 0; j < 3; j++) { u += s[j][i]; } rotate(u.begin(), u.begin() + k, u.end()); for (int j = 0; j < 3; j++) { s[j][i] = u[j]; } } } }; while (1) { bool flag = 1; for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) { for (int j = 0; j < 10; j++) { if (s[i][j] == t[i]) continue; flag = 0; if (j != 0) work(i, 10 - j); int i1 = t.find(s[i][0]); int j1 = 0; while (s[i1][j1] == t[i1]) j1++; if (j1 != 3) work(i1, (3 - j1 + 10) % 10); work(3, (i - i1 + 3) % 3); work(i1, 9); work(3, (i1 - i + 3) % 3); } } if (flag) break; } cout << ans.size() << '
'; for (auto s : ans) cout << s << '
';} G. Manhattan Walkåœ¨æ ¼å­ $(i,j)$ï¼Œå³è¾¹çš„æœŸæœ›æ—¶é—´è®°ä¸º $a$ï¼Œä¸‹è¾¹çš„æœŸæœ›æ—¶é—´è®°ä¸º $b$ï¼Œå‡è®¾ $a \le b$ã€‚åˆå§‹ç®­å¤´éšæœºæŒ‡å‘â€œå³â€æˆ–â€œä¸‹â€ï¼Œæ¦‚ç‡å„ $0.5$ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªç®­å¤´éƒ½æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå®šæ—¶å™¨ï¼Œåœ¨ $[0,p]$ å†…å‡åŒ€åˆ†å¸ƒåˆå§‹å€¼ï¼Œå½’é›¶åç¿»è½¬æ–¹å‘ã€‚ å¦‚æœ $a + p \le b$ï¼Œè¯´æ˜å³ä½¿ç­‰å¾…æ»¡ $p$ ç§’ç¿»æˆå³è¾¹å†èµ°ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯æ¯”èµ°ä¸‹è¾¹æ›´ä¼˜ã€‚ åˆå§‹å‘å³ï¼šç­‰å¾… $0$ï¼Œè€—æ—¶ $a$ã€‚ åˆå§‹å‘ä¸‹ï¼šç­‰å¾…æœŸæœ› $p/2$ ç§’ç¿»å‘å³ï¼Œå†èµ°å³è¾¹ $a$ã€‚ æ‰€ä»¥ç»¼åˆï¼š$E(i,j) =  rac12 \cdot a +  rac12 \cdot ( rac p 2 + a) = a +  rac p 4$ã€‚ å¦‚æœ $a + p > b$ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œâ€œç­‰ç¿»å‘å³â€ä¸ä¸€å®šæ¯”ç›´æ¥èµ°ä¸‹è¾¹å¥½ï¼Œè¦è§†å®šæ—¶å™¨å‰©ä½™æ—¶é—´ $x \in [0,p]$ è€Œå®šã€‚ åˆå§‹å‘å³ï¼ˆæ¦‚ç‡ 0.5ï¼‰ï¼šç›´æ¥èµ°å³ï¼Œè€—æ—¶ $a$ã€‚ åˆå§‹å‘ä¸‹ï¼ˆæ¦‚ç‡ 0.5ï¼‰ï¼šå®šæ—¶å™¨å‰©ä½™æ—¶é—´ $x \sim U[0,p]$ï¼š åŒºé—´ 1ï¼š$x < b-a$ï¼Œæ¦‚ç‡ $(b-a)/p$ï¼Œè€—æ—¶æœŸæœ›æ˜¯ $a + \mathbb{E}[x]$ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ $\mathbb{E}[x] =  rac{b-a}{2}$ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¿™æ®µçš„æœŸæœ›è€—æ—¶ = $a +  rac{b-a}{2} =  rac{a+b}{2}$ã€‚ åŒºé—´ 2ï¼š$x \ge b-a$ï¼Œæ¦‚ç‡ $(p - (b-a)) / p = (p - b + a)/p$ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶ç›´æ¥ä¸‹èµ°ï¼Œè€—æ—¶ $b$ã€‚ æ‰€ä»¥ç»¼åˆï¼š$E(i,j) = 0.5 \cdot a + 0.5 \cdot  rac{p - b + a}{p} \cdot b + 0.5 \cdot  rac{b-a}{p} \cdot  rac{a+b}{2}$ 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930void solve() { int r = read(), c = read(), p = read(); vector dp(r + 1, vector<double>(c + 1)); for (int i = r; i >= 1; i--) { for (int j = c; j >= 1; j--) { if (i == r and j == c) { dp[i][j] = 0; } else if (i == r) { dp[i][j] = 0.25 * p + dp[i][j + 1]; } else if (j == c) { dp[i][j] = 0.25 * p + dp[i + 1][j]; } else { auto a = dp[i][j + 1], b = dp[i + 1][j]; if (a > b) swap(a, b); if (a + p <= b) { dp[i][j] = 0.25 * p + a; } else { dp[i][j] = (p - b + a) * 0.5 / p * b + 0.5 * a + (b - a) * 0.5 / p * (a + b) * 0.5; } } } } printf("%.10lf
", dp[1][1]);}

posts.title: PSY2013 Lecture 01 Notes
posts.text: PSY2013 Research Methods in Psychology Ch01 Scientific Thinking in Psychology Ch02 Ethics in Psychological Research Scientific Thinking: Learning Objectives ç§‘å­¦æ€ç»´ï¼šå­¦ä¹ ç›®æ ‡ Defend the need for a research methods course for psychology students ä¸ºå¿ƒç†å­¦å­¦ç”Ÿå¼€è®¾ç ”ç©¶æ–¹æ³•è¯¾ç¨‹çš„å¿…è¦æ€§è¾©æŠ¤ Foundation for understanding other psychology courses, which are based on research ç ”ç©¶æ–¹æ³•è¯¾ç¨‹ä¸ºç†è§£å…¶ä»–åŸºäºç ”ç©¶çš„å¿ƒç†å­¦è¯¾ç¨‹å¥ å®šåŸºç¡€ Explain how the overall purpose of a methods course differs from other psychology courses è§£é‡Šæ–¹æ³•è¯¾ç¨‹çš„æ€»ä½“ç›®çš„å¦‚ä½•ä¸å…¶ä»–å¿ƒç†å­¦è¯¾ç¨‹ä¸åŒ Methods course teaches the process of acquiring knowledge about psychological phenomena æ–¹æ³•è¯¾ç¨‹æ•™æˆè·å–å¿ƒç†ç°è±¡çŸ¥è¯†çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ Identify and evaluate nonscientific ways of knowing about things in the world â€“ authority, reasoning, and experience è¯†åˆ«å’Œè¯„ä¼°å…³äºä¸–ç•Œäº‹ç‰©çš„éç§‘å­¦è®¤çŸ¥æ–¹å¼â€”â€”æƒå¨ã€æ¨ç†å’Œç»éªŒ Describe the attributes of science as a way of knowing æè¿°ç§‘å­¦ä½œä¸ºä¸€ç§è®¤çŸ¥æ–¹å¼çš„å±æ€§ Assumes determinism and discoverability å‡å®šå†³å®šè®ºå’Œå¯å‘ç°æ€§ Systematic observations, public knowledge, data-based conclusions ç³»ç»Ÿçš„è§‚å¯Ÿï¼Œå…¬å¼€çš„çŸ¥è¯†ï¼ŒåŸºäºæ•°æ®çš„ç»“è®º Distinguish science from pseudoscience and recognize the attributes of pseudoscientific thinking åŒºåˆ†ç§‘å­¦ä¸ä¼ªç§‘å­¦ï¼Œå¹¶è¯†åˆ«ä¼ªç§‘å­¦æ€ç»´çš„å±æ€§ Pseudoscience associates itself with real science, relies on anecdotal evidence, sidesteps falsification ä¼ªç§‘å­¦ä¸çœŸæ­£çš„ç§‘å­¦è”ç³»åœ¨ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œä¾èµ–è½¶äº‹è¯æ®ï¼Œå›é¿è¯ä¼ª Describe the main goals of research in psychology and relate them to various research strategies to be encountered later in the book æè¿°å¿ƒç†å­¦ç ”ç©¶çš„ä¸»è¦ç›®æ ‡ï¼Œå¹¶å°†å…¶ä¸ä¹¦ä¸­ç¨åæåˆ°çš„å„ç§ç ”ç©¶ç­–ç•¥è”ç³»èµ·æ¥ Ways of Knowing è®¤çŸ¥æ–¹å¼ Authority æƒå¨ Basing beliefs on what we are told by others (e.g., parents, teachers, textbooks) åŸºäºä»–äººå‘ŠçŸ¥çš„å†…å®¹å»ºç«‹ä¿¡å¿µï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œçˆ¶æ¯ã€è€å¸ˆã€æ•™ç§‘ä¹¦ï¼‰ Problem: authorities can be wrong é—®é¢˜ï¼šæƒå¨ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½æ˜¯é”™è¯¯çš„ Reason / Logical Argument æ¨ç† / é€»è¾‘è®ºè¯ Use of reason via conversation to come to a consensus é€šè¿‡å¯¹è¯ä½¿ç”¨æ¨ç†è¾¾æˆå…±è¯† Problems: initial assumptions may be incorrect; valid arguments can lead to opposite conclusions é—®é¢˜ï¼šåˆå§‹å‡è®¾å¯èƒ½æ˜¯é”™è¯¯çš„ï¼›æœ‰æ•ˆçš„è®ºè¯å¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´ç›¸åçš„ç»“è®º Empiricism / Direct Experience ç»éªŒä¸»ä¹‰ / ç›´æ¥ç»éªŒ Process of learning via direct observation or experience é€šè¿‡ç›´æ¥è§‚å¯Ÿæˆ–ç»éªŒå­¦ä¹ çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ Problems: experiences are limited to our interpretations; influenced by social cognition biases é—®é¢˜ï¼šç»éªŒå—åˆ°æˆ‘ä»¬è§£é‡Šçš„é™åˆ¶ï¼›å—åˆ°ç¤¾ä¼šè®¤çŸ¥åè§çš„å½±å“ Confirmation Bias ç¡®è®¤åè§: Tendency to seek information that supports oneâ€™s beliefs Belief Perseverance ä¿¡å¿µå›ºå®ˆ: Holding onto beliefs despite contradictory evidence Availability Heuristic å¯å¾—æ€§å¯å‘: Overestimating the frequency of memorable events Science as a Way of Knowing ç§‘å­¦ä½œä¸ºä¸€ç§è®¤çŸ¥æ–¹å¼ Attributes of Science ç§‘å­¦çš„å±æ€§ Assumes determinism (events have causes) and discoverability (causes can be discovered) å‡å®šå†³å®šè®ºï¼ˆäº‹ä»¶æœ‰åŸå› ï¼‰å’Œå¯å‘ç°æ€§ï¼ˆåŸå› å¯ä»¥è¢«å‘ç°ï¼‰ Systematic observations, less affected by bias ç³»ç»Ÿçš„è§‚å¯Ÿï¼Œå—åè§å½±å“è¾ƒå° Produces public knowledge (objectivity criterion) äº§ç”Ÿå…¬å¼€çš„çŸ¥è¯†ï¼ˆå®¢è§‚æ€§æ ‡å‡†ï¼‰ Produces data-based conclusions äº§ç”ŸåŸºäºæ•°æ®çš„ç»“è®º Produces tentative conclusions (subject to future research) äº§ç”Ÿæš‚å®šç»“è®ºï¼ˆå–å†³äºæœªæ¥çš„ç ”ç©¶ï¼‰ Asks answerable questions (empirical questions) posts.text: PSY2013 Research Methods in Psychology Ch05 Introduction to Experimental Research Ch06 Methodological Control in Experimental Research What is an Experiment? ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯å®éªŒï¼Ÿ Experiment å®éªŒ ç ”ç©¶è°ƒæŸ¥è‡³å°‘ä¸€ä¸ªè‡ªå˜é‡ (IV) X å¯¹è‡³å°‘ä¸€ä¸ªå› å˜é‡ (DV) Y çš„å½±å“ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä¿æŒæ‰€æœ‰å…¶ä»–å› ç´ ä¸å˜ã€‚ Independent Variable (IV) è‡ªå˜é‡ (IV): The manipulated variable that is believed to be the cause. è¢«è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯åŸå› çš„æ“ä½œå˜é‡ã€‚ Dependent Variable (DV) å› å˜é‡ (DV): The measured variable that is the outcome. ç»“æœçš„æµ‹é‡å˜é‡ã€‚ Extraneous Variables å¤–åœ¨å˜é‡: Factors held constant. ä¿æŒä¸å˜çš„å› ç´ ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Woodworthâ€™s â€˜Columbia Bibleâ€™ (1938): First distinguished between independent and dependent variables in experiments and showed preference for experimental over correlational research. åˆ›é€ ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´å› æœå…³ç³»çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚ The Logic of Experimental Research å®éªŒç ”ç©¶çš„é€»è¾‘ John Stuart Millâ€™s Inductive Logic çº¦ç¿°Â·æ–¯å›¾å°”ç‰¹Â·å¯†å°”çš„å½’çº³é€»è¾‘ Method of Agreement ä¸€è‡´æ³• If X, then Y (sufficiency -> X is sufficient for Y). å¦‚æœæœ‰ Xï¼Œåˆ™æœ‰ Yï¼ˆå……åˆ†æ¡ä»¶ -> X è¶³ä»¥å¯¼è‡´ Yï¼‰ã€‚ Method of Difference å·®å¼‚æ³• If not X, then not Y (necessity -> X is necessary for Y). å¦‚æœæ²¡æœ‰ Xï¼Œåˆ™æ²¡æœ‰ Yï¼ˆå¿…è¦æ¡ä»¶ -> X æ˜¯ Y æ‰€å¿…éœ€çš„ï¼‰ã€‚ Together, these methods enable us to conclude, with a high degree of confidence (but not absolute Independent Variables (IVs) ç¡®ç«‹è‡ªå˜é‡ (IV) Types of IVs è‡ªå˜é‡çš„ç±»å‹ Situational æƒ…å¢ƒæ€§: Different conditions or contexts. ä¸åŒçš„æ¡ä»¶æˆ–æƒ…å¢ƒã€‚ Task ä»»åŠ¡æ€§: Different tasks participants perform. å‚ä¸è€…æ‰§è¡Œçš„ä¸åŒä»»åŠ¡ã€‚ Instructional æŒ‡å¯¼æ€§: Different instructions given to participants. ç»™å‚ä¸è€…çš„ä¸åŒæŒ‡ç¤ºã€‚ Experimental Group å®éªŒç»„ Given treatment. æ¥å—å¤„ç†ã€‚ Control Group æ§åˆ¶ç»„ Treatment withheld. ä¸æ¥å—å¤„ç†ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Manipulate Situational IV æ“ä½œæƒ…å¢ƒæ€§è‡ªå˜é‡ Example: Personal space invasions in the lavatory by å’Œ Anderson (2009) å…³äºç”µå­æ¸¸æˆçš„ç ”ç©¶ã€‚ Manipulate Instructional IV æ“ä½œæŒ‡å¯¼æ€§è‡ªå˜é‡ Example: Priming study by Dijksterhuis and Knippenberg (1998). ä¾‹å­ï¼šDijksterhuis å’Œ Knippenberg (1998) çš„å¯åŠ¨ç ”ç©¶ã€‚ Controlling Extraneous Variables (EVs) æ§åˆ¶å¤–åœ¨å˜é‡ (EV) Confounds æ··æ·†å˜é‡ Any uncontrolled extraneous variable. ä»»ä½•æœªæ§åˆ¶çš„å¤–åœ¨å˜é‡ã€‚ Results could be due to IV or due to confound. ç»“æœå¯èƒ½æ˜¯ç”±äºè‡ªå˜é‡æˆ–æ··æ·†å˜é‡ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Example ä¾‹å­ Distributed practice study with different study schedules. ä¸åŒå­¦ä¹ æ—¶é—´è¡¨çš„åˆ†å¸ƒå¼ç»ƒä¹ ç ”ç©¶ã€‚ Measuring Dependent Variables (DVs) æµ‹é‡å› å˜é‡ (DVs) Dependent Variables å› å˜é‡ Any behaviors measured in an experiment. åœ¨å®éªŒä¸­æµ‹é‡çš„ä»»ä½•è¡Œä¸ºã€‚ å›é¡¾æµ‹é‡å°ºåº¦ï¼ˆåä¹‰ã€é¡ºåºã€é—´éš”ã€æ¯”ç‡ï¼‰ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Problems é—®é¢˜ Ceiling Effects å¤©èŠ±æ¿æ•ˆåº”: Task is too easy, all scores very high. ä»»åŠ¡å¤ªå®¹æ˜“ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰åˆ†æ•°éƒ½å¾ˆé«˜ã€‚ Floor Effects åœ°æ¿æ•ˆåº”: Task is too difficult, all scores very low. ä»»åŠ¡å¤ªéš¾ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰åˆ†æ•°éƒ½å¾ˆä½ã€‚ Subject Variables å—è¯•è€…å˜é‡Definition å®šä¹‰ Subject Variables å—è¯•è€…å˜é‡ Already-existing attributes of subjects in a study. ç ”ç©¶ä¸­å—è¯•è€…çš„æ—¢æœ‰å±æ€§ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Examples ä¾‹å­ Gender, age, religion, SES, personality characteristic. æ€§åˆ«ã€å¹´é¾„ã€å®—æ•™ã€ç¤¾ä¼šç»æµåœ°ä½ã€æ€§æ ¼ç‰¹å¾ã€‚ Drawing Conclusions with Subject Variables ä½¿ç”¨å—è¯•è€…å˜é‡å¾—å‡ºç»“è®º With a Manipulated IV ä½¿ç”¨æ“ä½œè‡ªå˜é‡ Assuming no confounds -> IV causes DV. å‡è®¾æ²¡æœ‰æ··æ·†å˜é‡ -> è‡ªå˜é‡å¯¼è‡´å› å˜é‡ã€‚ With a Subject Variable ä½¿ç”¨å—è¯•è€…å˜é‡ Groups may differ in several ways -> IV cannot be said to cause DV. å„ç»„å¯èƒ½åœ¨å¤šæ–¹é¢æœ‰æ‰€ä¸åŒ -> ä¸èƒ½è¯´è‡ªå˜é‡å¯¼è‡´å› å˜é‡ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Example ä¾‹å­ Self-esteem study with manipulated IV (feedback on test performance) and subject variable (low vs. high self-esteem). è‡ªå°Šç ”ç©¶ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨æ“ä½œè‡ªå˜é‡ï¼ˆæµ‹è¯•è¡¨ç°åé¦ˆï¼‰å’Œå—è¯•è€…å˜é‡ï¼ˆä½ vs. é«˜è‡ªå°Šï¼‰ã€‚ The Validity of Experimental Research å®éªŒç ”ç©¶çš„æ•ˆåº¦Types of Validity æ•ˆåº¦ç±»å‹ Statistical Conclusion Validity ç»Ÿè®¡ç»“è®ºæ•ˆåº¦ The extent a researcher uses statistics properly and draws the appropriate conclusions from the statistical analysis. ç ”ç©¶äººå‘˜é€‚å½“ä½¿ç”¨ç»Ÿè®¡æ–¹æ³•å¹¶ä»ç»Ÿè®¡åˆ†æä¸­å¾—å‡ºé€‚å½“ç»“è®ºçš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Construct Validity æ„å¿µæ•ˆåº¦ The extent to which the abstract construct can be inferred from the operational definition. ä»æ“ä½œå®šä¹‰æ¨æ–­æŠ½è±¡æ„å¿µçš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ External Validity å¤–éƒ¨æ•ˆåº¦ The extent to which research findings generalize to contexts other than those of the experiment. ç ”ç©¶å‘ç°æ¨å¹¿åˆ°å®éªŒä»¥å¤–ç¯å¢ƒçš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Internal Validity å†…éƒ¨æ•ˆåº¦ The degree to which an experiment is methodologically sound and confound-free. å®éªŒåœ¨æ–¹æ³•ä¸Šæ˜¯å¦å¥å…¨å’Œæ²¡æœ‰æ··æ·†å˜é‡çš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Threats to Internal Validity å†…éƒ¨æ•ˆåº¦çš„å¨èƒ History å†å²æ•ˆåº”: Results from a historical or external factor affecting the experimental group. ç”±äºå½±å“å®éªŒç»„çš„å†å²æˆ–å¤–éƒ¨å› ç´ å¯¼è‡´çš„ç»“æœã€‚ Maturation æˆç†Ÿæ•ˆåº”: Participants naturally change over time, independent of their participation in the study. å‚ä¸è€…éšç€æ—¶é—´è‡ªç„¶å˜åŒ–ï¼Œä¸ä»–ä»¬å‚ä¸ç ”ç©¶æ— å…³ã€‚ Regression to the Mean å‡å€¼å›å½’: æç«¯åˆ†æ•°åœ¨éšåçš„æµ‹è¯•ä¸­å¾€å¾€ä¼šè¶‹å‘äºå¹³å‡å€¼ã€‚ Testing and Instrumentation æµ‹è¯•å’Œä»ªå™¨æ•ˆåº”: éšç€æ—¶é—´çš„æ¨ç§»ï¼Œå‚ä¸è€…æˆ–æµ‹é‡å·¥å…·çš„å˜åŒ–ã€‚ Subject Selection å—è¯•è€…é€‰æ‹©: Groups are not equivalent. å„ç»„ä¸ç­‰ä»·ã€‚ Attrition é€€å‡ºæ•ˆåº”: Reduction in participant numbers due to dropouts. ç”±äºé€€å‡ºå¯¼è‡´çš„å‚ä¸è€…äººæ•°å‡å°‘ã€‚ --- Methodological Control æ–¹æ³•æ§åˆ¶Between-Subjects and Within-Subjects Design è¢«è¯•é—´è®¾è®¡å’Œè¢«è¯•å†…è®¾è®¡ Between-Subjects Design è¢«è¯•é—´è®¾è®¡ Each subject experiences only one level of the variable. æ¯ä¸ªå—è¯•è€…ä»…ç»å†ä¸€ä¸ªå˜é‡æ°´å¹³ã€‚ Solved by random assignment or matching. ä»…ä½¿ç”¨æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½é¡ºåºçš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­é›†ã€‚ Often achieved through a Latin Square design. é€šå¸¸é€šè¿‡æ‹‰ä¸æ–¹è®¾è®¡å®ç°ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Latin Square Design æ‹‰ä¸æ–¹è®¾è®¡ A special posts.text: PSY2013 Research Methods in Psychology Ch04 Sampling, Measurement, and Hypothesis Testing Who to Measure â€“ Sampling Procedures æµ‹é‡å¯¹è±¡ - æŠ½æ ·ç¨‹åºSamples vs. Populations æ ·æœ¬ vs. æ€»ä½“ Population æ€»ä½“ ç ”ç©¶äººå‘˜å¸Œæœ›é€šè¿‡ç ”ç©¶äº†è§£çš„ä¸€ç»„ä¸ªä½“ã€‚ Sample æ ·æœ¬ ä»æ€»ä½“ä¸­é€‰æ‹©çš„ä¸ªä½“ç¾¤ä½“ï¼Œç”¨äºä»£è¡¨æ€»ä½“è¿›è¡Œç ”ç©¶ã€‚ Sampling Procedure æŠ½æ ·ç¨‹åºProbability Sampling æ¦‚ç‡æŠ½æ · Simple Random Sampling ç®€å•éšæœºæŠ½æ · æ€»ä½“ä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸ªæˆå‘˜éƒ½æœ‰ç›¸ç­‰çš„æœºä¼šè¢«é€‰ä¸ºæ ·æœ¬æˆå‘˜ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å½©ç¥¨ã€‚ æœ‰æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨éšæœºæ•°ç”Ÿæˆå™¨ä»æ€»ä½“ä¸­é€‰æ‹©ã€‚ Stratified Sampling åˆ†å±‚æŠ½æ · Proportions of important subgroups in the population are represented precisely in the sample. æ€»ä½“ä¸­é‡è¦å­ç¾¤ä½“çš„æ¯”ä¾‹åœ¨æ ·æœ¬ä¸­è¢«ç²¾ç¡®ä»£è¡¨ã€‚ Example: 75% female; 25% male (2 strata). ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼š75%å¥³æ€§ï¼›25%ç”·æ€§ï¼ˆ2å±‚ï¼‰ã€‚ Cluster Sampling èšç±»æŠ½æ · Randomly select a cluster of individuals all having some feature in common. éšæœºé€‰æ‹©å…·æœ‰æŸäº›å…±åŒç‰¹å¾çš„ä¸ªä½“ç¾¤ä½“ã€‚ Example: Sample 3/20 dormitory students who live on-campus, and random select from each convenient, e.g., â€œsubject poolâ€. é€‰æ‹©å¯ç”¨å’Œæ–¹ä¾¿çš„å—è¯•è€…ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚â€œå—è¯•è€…æ± â€ã€‚ å—è¯•è€…è‡ªæ„¿å‚ä¸ã€‚ Purposive Sampling ç›®çš„æŠ½æ · Selecting specific individuals who meet certain criteria. é€‰æ‹©ç¬¦åˆç‰¹å®šæ ‡å‡†çš„ä¸ªä½“ã€‚ ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼šMilgramä¸ä½¿ç”¨å¤§å­¦ç”Ÿã€‚ Quota Sampling é…é¢æŠ½æ · Similar to stratified sampling, but non-random. ç±»ä¼¼äºåˆ†å±‚æŠ½æ ·ï¼Œä½†ééšæœºã€‚ Snowball Sampling æ»šé›ªçƒæŠ½æ · è¯·æ±‚å—è¯•è€…è®©ä»–ä»¬çš„æœ‹å‹ã€å®¶äººå’Œç†Ÿäººå‚ä¸ã€‚ é€šå¸¸é€šè¿‡åœ¨çº¿è°ƒæŸ¥è¿›è¡Œã€‚ What to Measure â€“ Varieties of Behavior æµ‹é‡å¯¹è±¡ - è¡Œä¸ºçš„ç§ç±»Developing Measures from Constructs ä»æ„å¿µä¸­å‘å±•æµ‹é‡å·¥å…· Reaction Time ååº”æ—¶é—´ One of psychologyâ€™s original methods. å¿ƒç†å­¦çš„åŸå§‹æ–¹æ³•ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚ Example: Mental chronometry (Donders). ä¾‹å­ï¼šå¿ƒç†è®¡æ—¶æ³•ï¼ˆDondersï¼‰ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Mental Rotation å¿ƒç†æ—‹è½¬ Construct: Visual imagery. æ„å¿µï¼šè§†è§‰æƒ³è±¡ã€‚ Measure: Reaction time. æµ‹é‡ï¼šååº”æ—¶é—´ã€‚ Evaluating Measures è¯„ä¼°æµ‹é‡å·¥å…· Reliability ä¿¡åº¦ Repeatability and consistency of measures. æµ‹é‡çš„é‡å¤æ€§å’Œä¸€è‡´æ€§ã€‚ Results from a minimum of measurement errors. æµ‹é‡è¯¯å·®æœ€å°åŒ–çš„ç»“æœã€‚ Quantified using correlation coefficient. ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸å…³ç³»æ•°é‡åŒ–ã€‚ Validity æ•ˆåº¦ Measures what it is designed to measure. æµ‹é‡å…¶è®¾è®¡æµ‹é‡çš„å†…å®¹ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Types of Validity æ•ˆåº¦ç±»å‹ Content Validity å†…å®¹æ•ˆåº¦: Measures broadly represent what the measure is supposed to measure. æµ‹é‡å¹¿æ³›ä»£è¡¨å…¶åº”æµ‹é‡çš„å†…å®¹ã€‚ Criterion Validity æ ‡å‡†æ•ˆåº¦: The extent to which a measure is related to some criterion (outcome variable). æµ‹é‡ä¸æŸäº›æ ‡å‡†ï¼ˆç»“æœå˜é‡ï¼‰ç›¸å…³çš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Concurrent: How well the measure predicts present performance. ç°æ—¶æ•ˆåº¦ï¼šæµ‹é‡é¢„æµ‹å½“å‰è¡¨ç°çš„æ•ˆæœå¦‚ä½•ã€‚ Predictive: How well the measure predicts future performance. é¢„æµ‹æ•ˆåº¦ï¼šæµ‹é‡é¢„æµ‹æœªæ¥è¡¨ç°çš„æ•ˆæœå¦‚ä½•ã€‚ Construct Validity æ„å¿µæ•ˆåº¦: The extent to which the abstract construct can be inferred from the operational definition. ä»æ“ä½œå®šä¹‰æ¨æ–­æŠ½è±¡æ„å¿µçš„ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Scales of Measurement æµ‹é‡å°ºåº¦ Nominal Scale åä¹‰å°ºåº¦ Category-defined, e.g., gender, ethnicity. ç±»åˆ«å®šä¹‰ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æ€§åˆ«ã€ç§æ—ã€‚ Ordinal Scale é¡ºåºå°ºåº¦ Rank order, e.g., order of finish in a test. æ’åºï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æµ‹è¯•ä¸­çš„å®Œæˆé¡ºåºã€‚ Interval Scale é—´éš”å°ºåº¦ Order + equal intervals, e.g., temperature scales. é¡ºåº + ç›¸ç­‰é—´éš”ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æ¸©åº¦åˆ»åº¦ã€‚ Ratio Scale æ¯”ç‡å°ºåº¦ Order + equal intervals + true zero point, e.g., weight. é¡ºåº + ç›¸ç­‰é—´éš” + çœŸå®é›¶ç‚¹ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚é‡é‡ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Example of Scales å°ºåº¦ç¤ºä¾‹ Nominal: Gender (male, female). Ordinal: Education level (high school, bachelorâ€™s, masterâ€™s). Interval: Temperature (Celsius). Ratio: Height (cm). Statistical Analysis ç»Ÿè®¡åˆ†æDescriptive Statistics æè¿°ç»Ÿè®¡ Frequency Distribution é¢‘æ•°åˆ†å¸ƒ Count or frequency for nominal/categorical data. åä¹‰/åˆ†ç±»æ•°æ®çš„è®¡æ•°æˆ–é¢‘ç‡ã€‚ Measures of Central Tendency é›†ä¸­è¶‹åŠ¿æµ‹é‡ What scores are at the center of a distribution. åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­å¿ƒçš„åˆ†æ•°ã€‚ Mean, median, mode. å¹³å‡æ•°ã€ä¸­ä½æ•°ã€ä¼—æ•°ã€‚ Measures of Variability å˜å¼‚æ€§æµ‹é‡ How spread out or dispersed scores are in a distribution. åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­åˆ†æ•°çš„åˆ†æ•£ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Range, standard deviation (SD), variance (VAR), interquartile range (IQR). èŒƒå›´ã€æ ‡å‡†å·®ï¼ˆSDï¼‰ã€æ–¹å·®ï¼ˆVARï¼‰ã€å››åˆ†ä½è·ï¼ˆIQRï¼‰ã€‚ Inferential Statistics æ¨è®ºç»Ÿè®¡ Inferential Statistics æ¨è®ºç»Ÿè®¡ Makes inferences and predictions about a population based on a sample of data. åŸºäºæ ·æœ¬æ•°æ®å¯¹æ€»ä½“è¿›è¡Œæ¨æ–­å’Œé¢„æµ‹ã€‚ Provide a way to test a claim or hypothesis using sample data. æä¾›ä¸€ç§ä½¿ç”¨æ ·æœ¬æ•°æ®æ£€éªŒä¸»å¼ æˆ–å‡è®¾çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ Hypothesis Testing å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒNull Hypothesis é›¶å‡è®¾ Definition å®šä¹‰ No relationship (â€œno differenceâ€) between variables in the population is expected. é¢„è®¡æ€»ä½“ä¸­å˜é‡ä¹‹é—´æ²¡æœ‰å…³ç³»ï¼ˆâ€œæ²¡æœ‰å·®å¼‚â€ï¼‰ã€‚ Alternative Hypothesis å¤‡æ‹©å‡è®¾ Definition å®šä¹‰ A relationship (â€œa differenceâ€) between variables in the population is expected. é¢„è®¡æ€»ä½“ä¸­å˜é‡ä¹‹é—´æœ‰å…³ç³»ï¼ˆâ€œæœ‰å·®å¼‚â€ï¼‰ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Significance Testing æ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ£€éªŒ If the observed p-value is less than a predefined value (alpha, Î±), the null hypothesis can be rejected. å¦‚æœè§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°çš„på€¼å°äºé¢„å®šä¹‰å€¼ï¼ˆalphaï¼ŒÎ±ï¼‰ï¼Œåˆ™å¯ä»¥æ‹’ç»é›¶å‡è®¾ã€‚ Common alpha level: Î± = 0.05. å¸¸è§çš„alphaæ°´å¹³ï¼šÎ± = 0.05ã€‚ Possible Errors å¯èƒ½çš„é”™è¯¯ Type I Error ç±»å‹Ié”™è¯¯ Rejecting a true null hypothesis (false positive). æ‹’ç»æ­£ç¡®çš„é›¶å‡è®¾ï¼ˆå‡é˜³æ€§ï¼‰ã€‚ Type II Error ç±»å‹IIé”™è¯¯ Failing to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative). æœªèƒ½æ‹’ç»é”™è¯¯çš„é›¶å‡è®¾ï¼ˆå‡é˜´æ€§ï¼‰ã€‚ Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Power åŠŸæ•ˆ The chance of rejecting a false null hypothesis. æ‹’ç»é”™è¯¯çš„é›¶å‡è®¾çš„æœºä¼šã€‚ Power = 1 - Î² (where Î² is the probability of a Type II error). åŠŸæ•ˆ = 1 - Î²ï¼ˆå…¶ä¸­Î²æ˜¯ç±»å‹IIé”™è¯¯çš„æ¦‚ç‡ï¼‰ã€‚ Beyond Hypothesis Testing è¶…è¶Šå‡è®¾æ£€éªŒConfidence Intervals ç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´ Definition å®šä¹‰ The range within which the population mean is likely to be found within a percentage of the time. æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼å¯èƒ½åœ¨ä¸€å®šç™¾åˆ†æ¯”æ—¶é—´å†…å‡ºç°çš„èŒƒå›´ã€‚ Example: A 95% confidence interval tells us that we can be 95% confident that the interval captures the population mean. ä¾‹å­ï¼š95%çš„ç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´å‘Šè¯‰æˆ‘ä»¬ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥95%ç¡®å®šè¯¥åŒºé—´åŒ…å«æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼ã€‚ Effect Size æ•ˆåº”é‡ Definition å®šä¹‰ Emphasizes the size of the difference between variables, not merely whether there is a difference. å¼ºè°ƒå˜é‡ä¹‹é—´å·®å¼‚çš„å¤§å°ï¼Œè€Œä¸ä»…ä»…æ˜¯æ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨å·®å¼‚ã€‚ Open Science, Pre-registration, and Replications å¼€æ”¾ç§‘å­¦ã€é¢„æ³¨å†Œå’Œå¤åˆ¶ç ”ç©¶Expanded Notes æ‰©å±•ç¬”è®°: Open Science å¼€æ”¾ç§‘å­¦ Promotes transparency and accessibility in scientific research. ä¿ƒè¿›ç§‘å­¦ç ”ç©¶çš„é€æ˜æ€§å’Œå¯è®¿é—®æ€§ã€‚ Pre-registration é¢„æ³¨å†Œ Registering study design and analysis plans before conducting the research. åœ¨è¿›è¡Œç ”ç©¶ä¹‹å‰æ³¨å†Œç ”ç©¶è®¾è®¡å’Œåˆ†æè®¡åˆ’ã€‚ Replications å¤åˆ¶ç ”ç©¶ Repeating studies to confirm findings and ensure reliability. é‡å¤ç ”ç©¶ä»¥ç¡®è®¤å‘ç°å¹¶ç¡®ä¿å¯é æ€§ã€‚ Summary æ€»ç»“ Various sampling procedures are available to find a representative sample from the population. æœ‰å¤šç§æŠ½æ ·ç¨‹åºå¯ç”¨äºä»æ€»ä½“ä¸­æ‰¾åˆ°å…·æœ‰ä»£è¡¨æ€§çš„æ ·æœ¬ã€‚ Statistics is the language used to communicate findings in the field of psychology. ç»Ÿè®¡æ˜¯å¿ƒç†å­¦é¢†åŸŸä¸­ç”¨äºäº¤æµå‘ç°çš„è¯­è¨€ã€‚ Hypothesis testing involves determining the likelihood that the observed results are due to chance. å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒæ¶‰åŠç¡®å®šè§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°çš„ç»“æœæ˜¯ç”±äºæœºä¼šçš„å¯èƒ½æ€§ã€‚ Beyond hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, effect sizes, and power are essential for understanding psychological phenomena. è¶…è¶Šå‡è®¾æ£€éªŒï¼Œç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´ã€æ•ˆåº”é‡å’ŒåŠŸæ•ˆå¯¹äºç†è§£å¿ƒç†ç°è±¡è‡³å…³é‡è¦ã€‚

posts.title: PSY2043 Ch01 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch01 The Nature of Psychology INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES Understand the scope of scientific psychology. The scope of psychology is broad, covering topics such as face recognition, social judgments, memory, obesity, violence, and many more. Understand differing historical perspectives on the topics within psychology. Know five contemporary perspectives within psychology. Historical perspectives Structralism (the analysis of mental structures) Functionalism (studying how the mind works so that an organism can adapt to and function in its environment) Behaviorism (the study of behavior without reference to consciousness) Gestalt psychology (which focuses on the patterns formed by stimuli and on the organization of experience) Psychoanalysis (which emphasizes the role of unconscious processes in personality development and motivation) Information-processing theory Psycholinguistics Neuropsychology 5 Contemporary perspectives Biological perspectives Behavioral perspectives Cognitive perspectives Psychoanalytic perspectives Subjectivist perspectives Be familiar with seven major subfields within contemporary psychology. Know four cutting-edge interdisciplinary approaches in psychology. 7 Major subfields Biological psychology Cognitive psychology Developmental psychology Social and personality psychology Clincial and counseling psychology School and educational psychology Organizational and engineering psychology 4 Cutting-edge interdisciplinary approaches in psychology Cognitive neuroscience â€“ learn how mental activities are executed in the brain (scanning). Evolutionary psychology â€“ psychological mechanisms have a genetic basis and in the past increased our ancestorsâ€™ chances of surviving and reproducing. Cultural psychology Postive psychology Define psychology. Give examples of psychological research. Psychology can be defined as the scientifc study of behavior and mental process. Examples Brain damage and face recognition Attributing traits to people Childhood amnesia Obesity Effects of media violence on childrenâ€™s aggresion Identify key ideas and debates that shaped the history of psychology. Give examples of five different perspectives within contemporary psychology. idea â€“ mind and behavior could be the subject of scientific analysis â€“ scientific psychology born debate â€“ nature vs nurture Explain how psychologists use the scientific method to uncover knowledge. Generating a hypothesis Testing it by using a scientific method Experimental method Correlational method Observational method State the principles that guide the ethical conduct of psychological research. Minimal risk Informed consent Right to privacy The Scope of Psychology To evaluate new claims made about psychology, you need to know(1) what psychological facts are already firmly established(2) the standards for scientific evidence. Psychology can be defined as the scientifc study of behavior and mental process. The Historical Origins of Psychology Nature-nurture debate Roots of psychology can be traced to the 4th and 5th centuries B.C. One of the earliest debates about human psychology focused on the question of whether human capabilities are inborn or acquired through experience (the natureâ€“nurture debate). The beginnings of scientific psychology ç§‘å­¦å¿ƒç†å­¦ Scientific psychology was born in the late nineteenth century with the idea that mind and behavior could be the subject of scientific analysis. The first experimental laboratory in psychology was established by Wilhelm Wundt at the University of Leipzig in 1879. ï¼ˆåä¹ä¸–çºªæœ« Wilhelm Wundt å»ºç«‹ï¼‰ Wilhelm Wundt: Introspectionï¼ˆå†…çœæ³•ï¼‰- observing and recording the nature of oneâ€™s own perceptions, thoughts, and feelings The early â€˜schoolsâ€™ of psychology in the twentieth century Structuralism and funtionalismï¼ˆç»“æ„ä¸»ä¹‰å’ŒåŠŸèƒ½ä¸»ä¹‰ï¼‰ Titchener â€“ structuralism â€“ the analysis of mental structures William James â€“ functionalism â€“ studying how the mind works to enable an organism to adapt to and function in its environment. Both structuralists and functionalists still regarded psychology as the science of conscious experience Behaviorismï¼ˆè¡Œä¸ºä¸»ä¹‰ï¼‰ Watson, and others ascribing to behaviorism, argued that nearly all behavior is a result of conditioning and the environment shapes behavior by reinforcing specific habits. Gestalt psychologyï¼ˆæ ¼å¼å¡”å¿ƒç†å­¦ï¼‰ The Gestalt psychologistsâ€™ primary interest was perception, and they believed that perceptual experiences depend on the patterns formed by stimuli and on the organization of experience. Psychoanalysisï¼ˆç²¾ç¥åˆ†æï¼‰ At the center of Freudâ€™s theory is the concept of the unconscious â€“ the thoughts attitudes, impulses, wishes, motivations, and emotions of which we are unaware. Later developments in twentieth-century psychology Information-processing theoryï¼ˆä¿¡æ¯å¤„ç†ç†è®ºï¼‰ Psycholinguisticsï¼ˆå¿ƒç†è¯­è¨€å­¦ï¼‰ Neuropsychologyï¼ˆç¥ç»å¿ƒç†å­¦ï¼‰ Contemporary Psychology Perspectives The biological perspective The behaviroal perspective The cognitive perspective The psychoanalytic perspective The subjectivist perspective An orientation toward understanding behavior and mental processes in terms of the subjective realities people actively construct. Relationships between psychological and biological perspectives Reductionism - Biological researchers often attempt to explain psychological principles in terms of biological ones Major subfields of psychology Biological psychology Cognitive psychology Developmental psychology Social and personality psychology Clincial and counseling psychology School and educational psychology Organizational and engineering psychology How Psychological Research is Done Generating hypotheses Experiments Correlation Observation Literature reviews Ethics of psychological

Feature integration theory ç‰¹å¾æ•´åˆè®º åœ¨å‰æ³¨æ„é˜¶æ®µï¼ŒåŸºæœ¬çš„ç‰¹å¾ï¼ˆprimitive featuresï¼‰ï¼Œè¢«çŸ¥è§‰åˆ° åœ¨æ³¨æ„é˜¶æ®µï¼Œusing attentions to â€œglueâ€ features together ç‰¹å¾æ•´åˆè®ºçš„é—®é¢˜ï¼šç ”ç©¶å‘ç°å¤ªå¤šçš„ â€primitivesâ€œ ï¼ˆåŸå§‹ç‰¹å¾ï¼‰å¹¶ä¸ç°å® æ›¿ä»£ç†è®º - åŠ¨æ€æ§åˆ¶è®ºï¼ˆdynamic control theoryï¼‰ system rearranges itself for different tasks Learn what the difference is between bottom-up and top-down processing. Bottom-up processes â€“ driven solely by the input Top-down processes â€“ driven by personâ€™s knowledge, experience, attention and expectations Learn why abstraction is important. Abstracted information takes less space and is therefore faster to work with than raw information. Explain how the perceptual system achieves and maintains constancy, and how this can cause illusions. illusions â€“ the perceptual systemâ€™s insistence on maintainingconstancies. Briefly describe the neural underpinnings of attention, recognition, and localization. Three separate brain systems The first system is generally associated with arousal. The second, or posterior system, selects objects on the basis of location, shape, or color. The third, or anterior system is responsible for guiding this process, depending on the goals of the viewer. The visual cortex operates according to the principle of division of labor. Localization is mediated by a region near the top of the cortex, and recognition by a region near the bottom of the cortex. Recognition processes are further subdivided into separate modules such as color, shape, and texture. Recognition and localization are carried out by two different regions of the visual cortex. Bars do not touch, used for nominal or ordinal scales. æ¡å½¢ä¸æ¥è§¦ï¼Œç”¨äºåä¹‰æˆ–é¡ºåºå°ºåº¦ã€‚ Central Tendency é›†ä¸­è¶‹åŠ¿ Definition å®šä¹‰ Measures that determine a single value to describe the center of a distribution. ç¡®å®šå•ä¸ªå€¼æ¥æè¿°åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­å¿ƒçš„æµ‹é‡ã€‚ Mean å¹³å‡æ•°: Sum of scores divided by the number of scores. æ€»åˆ†æ•°é™¤ä»¥åˆ†æ•°ä¸ªæ•°ã€‚ $$\text{Mean} (\mu) = \frac{\sum X}{N}$$ Median ä¸­ä½æ•°: Middle score in a distribution. åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­çš„ä¸­é—´åˆ†æ•°ã€‚ Mode ä¼—æ•°: Most frequently occurring score. å‡ºç°æœ€é¢‘ç¹çš„åˆ†æ•°ã€‚ Variability å˜å¼‚æ€§ Definition å®šä¹‰ Measure of how spread out the scores are in a distribution. æµ‹é‡åˆ†æ•°åœ¨åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­çš„åˆ†æ•£ç¨‹åº¦ã€‚ Range èŒƒå›´: Difference between the highest and lowest scores. æœ€é«˜åˆ†å’Œæœ€ä½åˆ†ä¹‹é—´çš„å·®ã€‚ Standard Deviation æ ‡å‡†å·®: Average distance between each score and the mean. æ¯ä¸ªåˆ†æ•°ä¸å¹³å‡æ•°ä¹‹é—´çš„å¹³å‡è·ç¦»ã€‚ $$\text{Standard Deviation} (\sigma) = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (X - \mu)^2}{N}}$$ Variance æ–¹å·®: Mean of the squared deviations. å¹³å‡å¹³æ–¹åå·®ã€‚ $$\text{Variance} (\sigma^2) = \frac{\sum (X - \mu)^2}{N}$$ Correlation ç›¸å…³æ€§ Pearson equation for the best-fitting line. ç¡®å®šæœ€ä½³æ‹Ÿåˆçº¿çš„æ–¹ç¨‹ã€‚ Equation æ–¹ç¨‹: $$Y = bX + a$$ $b$: Slope æ–œç‡ $a$: Y-intercept æˆªè· Part 2: Probability and Samples æ¦‚ç‡ä¸æ ·æœ¬Inferential Statistics æ¨è®ºç»Ÿè®¡ Definition å®šä¹‰ Methods for using sample data to make general conclusions about populations. ä½¿ç”¨æ ·æœ¬æ•°æ®å¯¹æ€»ä½“åšå‡ºä¸€èˆ¬ç»“è®ºçš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ z-Scores æ ‡å‡†åˆ†æ•° Formula å…¬å¼ $$z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma}$$ $$X = \mu + z\sigma$$ Purpose ç›®çš„ Specifies the precise location of each X value within a distribution. æŒ‡å®šæ¯ä¸ªXå€¼åœ¨åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­çš„ç²¾ç¡®ä½ç½®ã€‚ Example ä¾‹å­ Mean $\mu$ = 100, Standard Deviation $\sigma$ = 10, X = 130 â†’ z = 3 å¹³å‡æ•° $\mu$ = 100ï¼Œæ ‡å‡†å·® $\sigma$ = 10ï¼ŒX = 130 â†’ z = 3 Probability æ¦‚ç‡ Definition å®šä¹‰ Method for measuring the likelihood of obtaining a specific sample. æµ‹é‡è·å¾—ç‰¹å®šæ ·æœ¬çš„å¯èƒ½æ€§çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$P(A) = \frac{\text{number of outcomes classified as A}}{\text{total number of possible outcomes}}$$ Sampling and Probability æŠ½æ ·ä¸æ¦‚ç‡ Random Sampling éšæœºæŠ½æ · Each member of a population has an equal chance of being selected. æ€»ä½“çš„æ¯ä¸ªæˆå‘˜éƒ½æœ‰åŒç­‰çš„è¢«é€‰ä¸­æœºä¼šã€‚ Normal Distribution æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒ Symmetrical, bell-shaped distribution. å¯¹ç§°çš„é’Ÿå½¢åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚ Properties ç‰¹æ€§ Mean = Median = Mode å¹³å‡æ•° = ä¸­ä½æ•° = ä¼—æ•° Empirical Rule ç»éªŒæ³•åˆ™: ~68% within 1 SD, ~95% within 2 SDs, ~99.7% within 3 SDs 68%åœ¨1ä¸ªæ ‡å‡†å·®å†…ï¼Œ95%åœ¨2ä¸ªæ ‡å‡†å·®å†…ï¼Œ~99.7%åœ¨3ä¸ªæ ‡å‡†å·®å†… Central Limit Theorem ä¸­å¿ƒæé™å®šç† Definition å®šä¹‰ The distribution of sample means will be normal if the sample size is large enough (n â‰¥ 30). å¦‚æœæ ·æœ¬é‡è¶³å¤Ÿå¤§ï¼ˆn â‰¥ 30ï¼‰ï¼Œæ ·æœ¬å‡å€¼çš„åˆ†å¸ƒå°†æ˜¯æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚ Properties ç‰¹æ€§ Mean of sample means = Population mean æ ·æœ¬å‡å€¼çš„å¹³å‡æ•° = æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼ Standard Error æ ‡å‡†è¯¯å·®: $$\sigma_M = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$$ Part 3: Hypothesis Testing å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒHypothesis Testing å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒ Definition å®šä¹‰ Statistical method that uses sample data to evaluate a hypothesis about a population. ä½¿ç”¨æ ·æœ¬æ•°æ®è¯„ä¼°æ€»ä½“å‡è®¾çš„ç»Ÿè®¡æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ Steps æ­¥éª¤ State hypothesis about the population. é™ˆè¿°å…³äºæ€»ä½“çš„å‡è®¾ã€‚ Use hypothesis to predict the characteristics the sample should have. ä½¿ç”¨å‡è®¾é¢„æµ‹æ ·æœ¬åº”å…·æœ‰çš„ç‰¹å¾ã€‚ Obtain a sample from the population. ä»æ€»ä½“ä¸­è·å–æ ·æœ¬ã€‚ Compare data with the hypothesis prediction. å°†æ•°æ®ä¸å‡è®¾é¢„æµ‹è¿›è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒã€‚ Null Hypothesis (H0) é›¶å‡è®¾ States that there is no change or effect. å£°æ˜æ²¡æœ‰å˜åŒ–æˆ–æ•ˆæœã€‚ Alternative Hypothesis (H1) å¤‡æ‹©å‡è®¾ States that there is a change or effect. å£°æ˜å­˜åœ¨å˜åŒ–æˆ–æ•ˆæœã€‚ Critical Regions and Alpha Level ä¸´ç•ŒåŒºå’Œæ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³ Critical Region ä¸´ç•ŒåŒº Extreme sample values that are very unlikely to occur if H0 is true. å¦‚æœé›¶å‡è®¾æˆç«‹ï¼Œæä¸å¯èƒ½å‘ç”Ÿçš„æ ·æœ¬å€¼ã€‚ Alpha Level (Î±) æ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³ Probability value used to define â€œvery unlikelyâ€ outcomes. ç”¨äºå®šä¹‰â€œæä¸å¯èƒ½â€ç»“æœçš„æ¦‚ç‡å€¼ã€‚ Common Î± values å¸¸ç”¨Î±å€¼: 0.05, 0.01, 0.001 Errors in Hypothesis Testing å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒä¸­çš„é”™è¯¯ Type I Error (Î±) ä¸€ç±»é”™è¯¯ Rejecting H0 when it is true. æ‹’ç»æˆç«‹çš„é›¶å‡è®¾ã€‚ False positive å‡é˜³æ€§ Type II Error (Î²) äºŒç±»é”™è¯¯ Failing to reject H0 when it is false. æœªæ‹’ç»é”™è¯¯çš„é›¶å‡è®¾ã€‚ False negative å‡é˜´æ€§ Statistical Power ç»Ÿè®¡åŠŸæ•ˆ Definition å®šä¹‰ Probability that the test will correctly reject a false null hypothesis. æ£€éªŒæ­£ç¡®æ‹’ç»é”™è¯¯çš„é›¶å‡è®¾çš„æ¦‚ç‡ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$\text{Power} = 1 - \beta$$ Measuring Effect Size æµ‹é‡æ•ˆæœå¤§å° Cohenâ€™s d ç§‘æ©çš„d Measures the size of the mean difference in terms of standard deviation units. ä»¥æ ‡å‡†å·®å•ä½è¡¡é‡å¹³å‡å·®å¼‚çš„å¤§å°ã€‚ Part 4: t-Tests tæ£€éªŒThe t Statistic tç»Ÿè®¡é‡ Definition å®šä¹‰ Used to test hypotheses about an unknown population mean when the population standard deviation is also unknown. ç”¨äºåœ¨æ€»ä½“æ ‡å‡†å·®æœªçŸ¥çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹æ£€éªŒæœªçŸ¥æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼çš„å‡è®¾ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$t = \frac{M - \mu}{s_M}$$ $s_M$: Estimated standard error ä¼°è®¡æ ‡å‡†è¯¯å·® Degrees of Freedom è‡ªç”±åº¦ Definition å®šä¹‰ Number of scores in a sample that are independent and free to vary. æ ·æœ¬ä¸­ç‹¬ç«‹ä¸”è‡ªç”±å˜åŒ–çš„åˆ†æ•°æ•°é‡ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$df = n - 1$$ Hypothesis Tests with the t Statistic ä½¿ç”¨tç»Ÿè®¡é‡çš„å‡è®¾æ£€éªŒ Steps æ­¥éª¤ State the hypotheses and select an alpha level. é™ˆè¿°å‡è®¾å¹¶é€‰æ‹©æ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³ã€‚ Locate the critical region using df and alpha level. ä½¿ç”¨è‡ªç”±åº¦å’Œæ˜¾è‘—æ€§æ°´å¹³æ‰¾åˆ°ä¸´ç•ŒåŒºã€‚ Calculate the test statistic. è®¡ç®—æ£€éªŒç»Ÿè®¡é‡ã€‚ Make a decision. åšå‡ºå†³å®šã€‚ Independent-Measures t Test ç‹¬ç«‹æ ·æœ¬tæ£€éªŒ Purpose ç›®çš„ Determine whether the sample mean difference indicates a real mean difference between two populations. ç¡®å®šæ ·æœ¬å‡å€¼å·®å¼‚æ˜¯å¦è¡¨ç¤ºä¸¤ä¸ªæ€»ä½“ä¹‹é—´çš„çœŸå®å‡å€¼å·®å¼‚ã€‚ Pooled Variance åˆå¹¶æ–¹å·® Definition å®šä¹‰ Provides an unbiased basis for calculating the standard error. æä¾›è®¡ç®—æ ‡å‡†è¯¯å·®çš„æ— ååŸºç¡€ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$s_p^2 = \frac{SS_1 + SS_2}{df_1 + df_2}$$ Repeated-Measures t Test é‡å¤æµ‹é‡tæ£€éªŒ Definition å®šä¹‰ Evaluate the mean difference between two treatment conditions using data from a single sample. ä½¿ç”¨å•ä¸ªæ ·æœ¬çš„æ•°æ®è¯„ä¼°ä¸¤ä¸ªå¤„ç†æ¡ä»¶ä¹‹é—´çš„å¹³å‡å·®å¼‚ã€‚ Difference Score å·®å¼‚åˆ†æ•°: $$D = X_2 - X_1$$ Confidence Intervals ç½®ä¿¡åŒºé—´ Definition å®šä¹‰ Range of values that estimate the unknown population mean. ä¼°è®¡æœªçŸ¥æ€»ä½“å‡å€¼çš„å€¼èŒƒå›´ã€‚ Formula å…¬å¼: $$\mu = M \pm t(s_M)$$

posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch02 Biological Foundations of Psychology INTENDED LEARNING OUTCOMES Understand the organization and the physiology of the human brain. Have learned the research methods used to study the brain. computerized axial tomography (CT) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) positron emission tomography (PET) Be able to consider evolutionary arguments. Darwin â€“ Nature selection â€“ variations on inheritable traits that most contribute to an organismâ€™s survival that are passed on to the next generation. Explain the basics of the biology of the brain. Identify key areas in the human brain, including their function. Understand key principles concerning the heredity of behavior. An individualâ€™s hereditary potential, which is transmitted by the chromosomes and genes, influences his or her psychological and physical characteristics. Synaptic transmission and neural codingNeurotransmittersInhibitory neurotransmitters GABA â€“ Major inhibitory neurotransmitter in brain. Drugs that alleviate anxiety enhance activity of GABA. Serotonin â€“ Important in mood and social behavior. Drugs that alleviate depression and anxiety increase serotonin levels in synapse. Excitatory neurotransmitters Acetylcholine â€“ Involved in memory and attention; decreases associated with Alzheimerâ€™s disease. Also transmits signals between nerve and muscle. Norepinephrine â€“ Increased by psycho-timulants. Low levels contribute to depression. Dopamine â€“ Mediates the effects of natural rewards (food and sex, for example) and drugs of abuse. Glutamate â€“ Major excitatory neurotransmitter in brain. Involved in learning and memory. posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch07 Learning and Conditioning Intended Learning Outcomes Understand the history of the study of animal and human learning. Know the different types of conditioning and the way in which they are studied. Understand the brain physiology underlying learning processes. Know the topics of cognition and motivation, as they interact with learning. Identify different types of learning such as: classical versus instrumental conditioning, and observational learning. Explain the empirical paradigms used to study learning processes. Identify situations in which cognitions and/or motivations affect learning. posts.title: PSY2043 Ch16 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch16 Treatment of Mental Health Problems Intended Learning Outcomes Be familiar with the historical background and current trends in the treatment of abnormal behavior, in particular deinstitutionalization and reinstitutionalization. Deinstitutionalization 1960s movement of patients from hospitals to community-based servicesx Be able to describe the following approaches to psychotherapy, including the therapistâ€™s techniques and the patientâ€™s or clientâ€™s experiences that are presumed to yield improvement: Psychoanalysis and psychodynamic therapies; Behavior therapies; Cognitive-behavior therapies; Humanistic therapies; Family and marital therapies. Psychoanalysis and psychodynamic therapies Techniques: free association, dream analysis, transference. Behavior therapies Learning & conditioning Systematic desensitization In vivo exposure Selective reinforcement Modelling Behavioral rehearsal Self-regulation Cognitive-behavior therapies Humanistic therapies Client-centred therapy Family and marital therapies Be familiar with the techniques, advantages, and disadvantages of the two forms of biological therapy; be able to describe the major classes of psychotherapeutic drugs, their effects, and their applications to mental disorders. Electroconvulsive therapy Advantage â€“ Subject of controversy but effective in bringing some out of severe depression faster than drug therapy Disadvantage â€“ Can cause permanent memory loss and confusion Drug therapy Antipsychotic drugs â€“ alter levels of the dopamine â€“ schizophrenia Antidepressant drugs â€“ affecting levels of the neurotransmitters serotonin and norepinephrine â€“ Lithium â€“ Regulates levels of serotonin, norepinephrine, and other neurotransmitters â€“ bipolar disorders Antianxiety drugs â€“ Depresses central nervous system Stimulants â€“ Increasing levels of dopamine Be familiar with the suggestions offered for promoting your own emotional well-being. Accept your feelings Know your vulnerabilities Develop your talents and interests Become involved with other people Know when to seek help HISTORICAL BACKGROUND Earliest belief â€“ demon-possessed é¬¼é™„èº« å¤ä¸­å›½ï¼šé˜´é˜³å¤±è¡¡ Hippocratesï¼šdisturbance in body fluids ä½“æ¶²ç´Šä¹± Middle agesï¼šdemon-possessed Early asylums 1792 Philippe Pinel Morden treatment facilitiesProfessionals who provide psychotherapyTECHNIQUES OF PSYCHOTHERAPYBehavior therapies è¡Œä¸ºç–—æ³• ä»¥å­¦ä¹ åŠæ¡ä»¶ä½œç”¨åŸåˆ™ä¸ºåŸºç¡€æ‰€å‘å±•çš„æ²»ç–—æ–¹æ³• Systematic desensitization ç³»ç»Ÿè„±æ•æ³• In vivo exposure å®æ™¯æš´éœ²æ³• Flooding Selective reinforcement Modeling æ¨¡ä»¿ è§‚å¯Ÿä¸€ä½æ²»ç–—å¸ˆæ¡ç€ä¸€åªè›‡ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å‡è½»æƒ§è›‡è€…å¯¹è›‡çš„ææƒ§ Behavioral rehearsal è¡Œä¸ºæ¼”ç»ƒ æ²»ç–—å¸ˆå¸®åŠ©æ‚£è€…é¢„æ¼”æˆ–ç»ƒä¹ æ›´é€‚å½“çš„è¡Œä¸º Self-regulation Cognitive-behavior therapies è®¤çŸ¥è¡Œä¸ºç–—æ³•Treatment methods that use behavior modification techniques but also incorporate procedures designed to change maladaptive beliefs. Psychodynamic therapies å¿ƒç†åŠ¨åŠ›å­¦ç–—æ³• Traditional psychoanalysis Through free association, dream analysis, and transference, attempts to discover the unconscious basis of the clientâ€™s current problems so as to deal with them in a more rational way. Contemporary psychodynamic therapies (e.g., interpersonal therapy) More structured and short-term than traditional psychoanalysis; emphasize the way the client is currently interacting with others. posts.title: PSY2043 Ch17 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch17 Social Influence Intended Learning Outcomes Explore how the presence of others influences peopleâ€™s behavior. Deindividuation Bystander effects Social facilitation & inhibition Cover how deindividuation and bystanders influence social behavior. Deindividuation enhancing group identity promotes conformity to situation-specific social norms Bystander effects â€“ people are less likely to help if others are present Pluralistic ignorance â€“ everybody in group misleads everybody else by defining situation as non-emergency Diffusion of responsibility â€“ Presence of others, even imagined others, diffuses responsibility so no one person feels need to act Be introduced to classic experiments on compliance and obedience. Aschâ€™s experiment â€“ unanimous agreement among a group exerts strong pressures on individual to conform, even when judgements clearly wrong Milgramâ€™s classical experiment Learn how the classic Zimbardo Prison Experiment illustrates the power of situations and institutional norms. Institutions have norms that strongly govern the behavior of people who occupy critical roles within the institution. An example of how institutional norms shape group interactions is provided by the Stanford Prison Experiment, in which ordinary young men were randomly assigned roles of â€˜prisonerâ€™ and â€˜guardâ€™ in a simulated prison. Define the fundamental attribution error and provide an example. Fundamental attribution error â€“ tendency to explain otherâ€™s actions by overestimating personality influence but underestimating situational influence. e.g. Imagine you witness a colleague arriving late to an important meeting. Instead of considering external factors like traffic or a family emergency, you attribute their tardiness to a lack of punctuality or irresponsibility (internal, dispositional factors). In reality, the colleague might have faced unexpected traffic delays, highlighting the fundamental attribution error by focusing on the personâ€™s traits rather than the situation. Explain when and why social facilitation vs. social inhibition occurs. Social facilitation â€“ simple or well-learned tasks Social inhibition â€“ complex or poorly learned tasks Why â€“ the presence of others narrows peopleâ€™s attention Describe how deindividuation can produce aggression. Creates increased sensitivity to situation-specific social norms linked with the group. Minimizes peopleâ€™s personal identities Reduces sense of accountability Explain pluralistic ignorance and why it matters. everybody in group misleads everybody else by defining situation as non-emergency Discuss the differences between informational and normative social influence. Informational social conformity â€“ we conform because we believe that other peopleâ€™s interpretations of an ambiguous situation are more correct than our own. Normative social influence â€“ we conform because we believe that other peopleâ€™s interpretations of an ambiguous situation are more correct than our own. Explain the importance of Milgramâ€™s experiments on obedience to authority. Showed that ordinary people would obey experimenterâ€™s order to deliver strong electric shocks to innocent victim Discuss various explanations for why people change their attitudes to reflect their past behavior. Cognitive dissonance theory â€“ when peopleâ€™s behavior conflicts with their attitudes it creats an uncomfortable tension that motivates them to change their attitudes to be more in line with their actions. Rationalization, Self-justification Self-perception theory â€“ stating that inner turmoil does not necessarily occur. To the extent that internal cues are weak, ambiguous, or uninterpretable, people may simply infer their attitudes from their past behavior. Explain group polarization and why it happens. Group polarization: The group decision is in the same direction but is more extreme than the average of the group membersâ€™ initial positions. This is not just public conformity; group membersâ€™ private attitudes typically shift in response to the group discussion as well. The group polarization effect is due in part to informational social influence, in which group members learn new information and hear novel arguments that are relevant to the decision under discussion. Group polarization is also produced by normative social influence, in which people compare their own initial views with the norms of the group. They may then adjust their position to conform to that of the majority. The Presence of OthersSocial facilitation and social inhibitionDeindividuationBystander effectsCompliance and ObedianceComformity to a MajorityMinority influenceObediance to AuthorityInternalizationSelf-justificationReference groups and idenitifacationGroup InteractionsInstitutional normsGroup decision makingRecap: Social Psychological Views of the Seemingly Inexplicable

posts.text: PSY2033 Developmental Psychology Ch02 Theory and Research Learning Objectives å­¦ä¹ ç›®æ ‡ Describe the purpose of a theory in research and two theoretical issues on which developmental scientists differ.æè¿°ç†è®ºåœ¨ç ”ç©¶ä¸­çš„ç›®çš„ä»¥åŠå‘å±•ç§‘å­¦å®¶å­˜åœ¨åˆ†æ­§çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªç†è®ºé—®é¢˜ã€‚ Summarize the main theories of human development.æ¦‚è¿°äººç±»å‘å±•çš„ä¸»è¦ç†è®ºã€‚ Describe the methods of developmental research used to collect data and the advantages and disadvantages of each.æè¿°ç”¨äºæ”¶é›†æ•°æ®çš„å‘å±•ç ”ç©¶æ–¹æ³•åŠå…¶ä¼˜ç¼ºç‚¹ã€‚ Explain ethical guidelines for researchers who study people.è§£é‡Šç ”ç©¶äººç±»çš„ä¼¦ç†æŒ‡å—ã€‚ Basic Theoretical Terms åŸºæœ¬ç†è®ºæœ¯è¯­Theory ç†è®º Definition å®šä¹‰ Logically related concepts that describe and explain development, predict behavior under certain conditions, and uncover connections between isolated data. é€»è¾‘ç›¸å…³çš„æ¦‚å¿µï¼Œç”¨äºæè¿°å’Œè§£é‡Šå‘å±•ï¼Œé¢„æµ‹åœ¨ç‰¹å®šæ¡ä»¶ä¸‹å¯èƒ½å‘ç”Ÿçš„è¡Œä¸ºï¼Œå¹¶å‘ç°å­¤ç«‹æ•°æ®ä¹‹é—´çš„è”ç³»ã€‚ Hypotheses å‡è®¾ Definition å®šä¹‰ Explanations that can be tested by further research. å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡è¿›ä¸€æ­¥ç ”ç©¶æ£€éªŒçš„è§£é‡Šã€‚ Two Theoretical Issues ä¸¤ä¸ªç†è®ºé—®é¢˜ Is development active or reactive?å‘å±•æ˜¯ä¸»åŠ¨çš„è¿˜æ˜¯è¢«åŠ¨çš„ï¼Ÿ Is development continuous or discontinuous?å‘å±•æ˜¯è¿ç»­çš„è¿˜æ˜¯é—´æ–­çš„ï¼Ÿ Active vs. Reactive ä¸»åŠ¨ vs è¢«åŠ¨Mechanistic Model æœºæ¢°æ¨¡å‹ Definition å®šä¹‰ Human development as a series of predictable responses to stimuli; reactive; people are like machines. äººç±»å‘å±•è¢«è§†ä¸ºå¯¹åˆºæ¿€çš„å¯é¢„æµ‹ååº”ï¼›è¢«åŠ¨çš„ï¼›äººå¦‚åŒæœºå™¨ã€‚ é…—é…’ï¼šæœºæ¢°ä¸»ä¹‰ç†è®ºå®¶ä¼šå¯»æ‰¾ç¯å¢ƒå› ç´ ï¼Œå¦‚å¹¿å‘Šå’ŒåŒä¼´å½±å“ã€‚ Organismic Model æœ‰æœºæ¨¡å‹ Definition å®šä¹‰ Human development is internally initiated by an active organism; occurs in a sequence of qualitatively different stages. posts.title: PSY2043 Ch15 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch15 Psychological Disorders Intended Learning Outcomes Know the four criteria that may be used in defining abnormality as well as the characteristics that are considered indicative of normality. Abnormality Deviation from cultural norms åç¦»æ–‡åŒ–è§„èŒƒ Deviation from statistical norms åç¦»ç»Ÿè®¡å¸¸æ¨¡ Maladaptive behavior è¡Œä¸ºçš„é€‚åº”æ€§ï¼ˆå¯¹ä¸ªäººæˆ–ç¤¾ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿä¸åˆ©å½±å“ï¼‰ Personal distress ä¸ªäººç—›è‹¦ Nomality Appropriate perception of reality å¯¹ç°å®çš„æ­£ç¡®çŸ¥è§‰ Ability to exercise voluntary control over behavior è‡ªä¸»æ§åˆ¶è¡Œä¸º Self-esteem and acceptance è‡ªå°ŠåŠè‡ªæˆ‘æ¥çº³ Ability to form affectionate relationships å½¢æˆäº²å¯†å…³ç³»çš„èƒ½åŠ› Productivity å…·æœ‰ç”Ÿäº§åŠ› Understand the advantages and disadvantages of classifying abnormal behavior into categories. Advantages Aids diagnosis & treatment Enables quick and concise communication Disadvantages Labeling induces us to overlook unique features of person and expect person to conform to classification doesnâ€™t tell us how the symptoms originated or what causes them to continue stigma in many societies Know the broad perspectives of the biological, psychoanalytic, behavior, cognitive, and sociocultural models. Biological â€“ brain disorders Psychoanalytic â€“ unconscious conflicts Behavior â€“ conditioning and reinforcement & learned fear & learned maladaptive behavior Cognitive â€“ maladaptive cognitive process Sociocultural models â€“ social context Vulnerability-stress model â€“ the interaction between a predisposition that make a person vulnerable to a particular health problem and stressful environmental Describe four types of anxiety disorders. Understand the development of anxiety disorders from the standpoint of biological, cognitive, behavioral, and psychodynamic theories. Know what research on biological factors has contributed thus far to our understanding of these disorders. Anxiety disorders Generalized anxiety (constant worry and tension) Panic disorders (sudden attacks of overwhelming apprehension) Phobias (irrational fears of specific objects or situations) Obsessive-compulsive disorder Describe the two major mood disorders and to compare cognitive-behavior, psychoanalytic, and interpersonal theories of depression. Mood disorders Depressive disorder Bipolar disorder Cognitive theories attribute depression to pessimistic views of the self, the world, and the future and to maladaptive attributional styles. Psychodynamic theories view depression as a reactivation of loss of parental affection in a person who is dependent on external approval and tends to turn anger inward. Interpersonal theories view depression as the result of insecurities about relationships and maladaptive patterns of social interaction. Know the defining characteristics of schizophrenia and be able to give examples of each characteristic. Disturbances of thought and attention loosening of associations â€“ word salad delusion Disturbances of perception hallucinations Disturbances of emotional expression express emotions that are inappropriately linked to the situation or to the thought being expressed, such as smiling while speaking of tragic events. Be familiar with the research on the causes of schizophrenia; be able to discuss the probable contributions of genetic, biochemical, and psychological factors. Genetic â€“ Schizophrenia clearly is transmitted genetically Biochemical â€“ have problems in dopamine regulation Psychological â€“ Psychosocial factors play important role in overall severity & triggering of new episodes Define personality disorders; know the defining characteristics and probable causes of antisocial personalities and borderline personality disorder. Definition â€“ long-standing patterns of maladaptive behavior involving difficulties in coping with stress or solving problems ASPD Biological factors Genetic factors play a role in development of antisocial personality â€“ twin studies confirm genetic component Deficits in executive functions could lead to poor impulse control & difficulty in anticipating consequences Social factors Neglectful & hostile parents may contribute to disorder Personality factors Children with antisocial personalities process information about social interactions in ways that promote aggressive reactions BPD Psychoanalytic theorists argue poorly developed views of self & others stem from poor early relationships with caregivers Others argue deficit in ability to regulate emotions Understand the patterns of behavior that constitute autism spectrum disorders. Describe the biological causes of autism spectrum disorders. Diagnose â€“ three types of deficits Social interaction â€“ lack of connection with others Communication â€“ difficulties in communication & speech Activities & interests â€“ preoccupation/routines/rituals Biological causes Genetics Neurological factors â€“ disruption in normal development & organization of the brain DEFINING ABNORMALITY å˜æ€çš„å®šä¹‰Deviation from cultural norms åç¦»æ–‡åŒ–è§„èŒƒDeviation from statistical norms åç¦»ç»Ÿè®¡å¸¸æ¨¡Maladaptive behavior é€‚åº”ä¸è‰¯çš„è¡Œä¸ºï¼ˆå¯¹ä¸ªäººæˆ–ç¤¾ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿä¸åˆ©å½±å“ï¼‰Personal distress ä¸ªäººç—›è‹¦ depends on socialization, it is also a process of cognitive development: è™½ç„¶é“å¾·è¡Œä¸ºä¾èµ–äºç¤¾ä¼šåŒ–ï¼Œä½†å®ƒä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè®¤çŸ¥å‘å±•çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ One very influential theory was developed by Lawrence Kohlberg: åŠ³ä¼¦æ–¯Â·ç§‘å°”ä¼¯æ ¼å‘å±•äº†ä¸€ä¸ªéå¸¸æœ‰å½±å“åŠ›çš„ç†è®º Kohlberg presented â€œmoral dilemmasâ€ to children and studied how their answers changed with development: Stage 6: Universal principles. å‰ä¹ ä¿—æ°´å¹³ é˜¶æ®µ1: æœä»å’Œæƒ©ç½šã€‚ é˜¶æ®µ2: è‡ªæˆ‘åˆ©ç›Šã€‚ ä¹ ä¿—æ°´å¹³ é˜¶æ®µ3: è‰¯å¥½çš„äººé™…å…³ç³»ã€‚ é˜¶æ®µ4: ç»´æŠ¤ç¤¾ä¼šç§©åºã€‚ åä¹ ä¿—æ°´å¹³ é˜¶æ®µ5: ç¤¾ä¼šå¥‘çº¦å’Œä¸ªäººæƒåˆ©ã€‚ é˜¶æ®µ6: æ™®éåŸåˆ™ã€‚ Evaluating Kohlbergâ€™s Theory è¯„ä»·æŸ¯å°”ä¼¯æ ¼çš„ç†è®º æ”¯æŒ: é“å¾·åˆ¤æ–­ä¸å¹´é¾„ã€æ•™è‚²ã€æ™ºå•†å’Œç¤¾ä¼šç»æµåœ°ä½ç­‰å› ç´ çš„ç›¸å…³æ€§ã€‚ æ‰¹è¯„: åŒ…æ‹¬ä½ä¼°å„¿ç«¥çš„çµæ´»æ€§ï¼Œå¿½è§†æƒ…æ„Ÿæˆåˆ†ï¼Œä»¥åŠå¿½è§†é“å¾·æ¨ç†ä¸è¡Œä¸ºä¹‹é—´çš„åŒºåˆ«ã€‚ è®¤çŸ¥å‘å±• â‰  åŒç­‰æ°´å¹³çš„é“å¾·å‘å±• çˆ¶æ¯çš„å½±å“ï¼ˆæƒå¨å‹ï¼‰ Gilliganâ€™s Theory å‰åˆ©æ ¹çš„ç†è®º æ€§åˆ«åè§: æŸ¯å°”ä¼¯æ ¼çš„ç†è®ºå¯èƒ½åå‘ç”·æ€§çš„æ¨ç†é£æ ¼ã€‚ å¥³æ€§è§†è§’: å¼ºè°ƒå…³æ€€å’Œé¿å…ä¼¤å®³ã€‚ Prosocial Behavior äº²ç¤¾ä¼šè¡Œä¸ºProsocial â€“ care-oriented moral reasoning Alternative to Kohlbergâ€™s justice system Development å‘å±• å¢åŠ : ä»ç«¥å¹´åˆ°é’å°‘å¹´æœŸã€‚ æ€§åˆ«å·®å¼‚: å¥³å­©å¾€å¾€è¡¨ç°å‡ºæ›´å¤šçš„äº²ç¤¾ä¼šè¡Œä¸ºã€‚ Moral Dilemmas é“å¾·å›°å¢ƒ æƒ…æ™¯: ä¸€ä¸ªäººçš„éœ€æ±‚æˆ–æ„¿æœ›ä¸å¦ä¸€ä¸ªäººå‘ç”Ÿå†²çªã€‚ School Achievement å­¦æ ¡æˆç»©Factors å½±å“å› ç´  Motivation: Typically declines in high school. Self-efficacy: Belief in oneâ€™s ability to master tasks. Twice as important as IQ in accounting for final grades. åŠ¨æœº: é€šå¸¸åœ¨é«˜ä¸­ä¸‹é™ã€‚ è‡ªæˆ‘æ•ˆèƒ½æ„Ÿ: ç›¸ä¿¡è‡ªå·±èƒ½æŒæ¡ä»»åŠ¡çš„èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚ åœ¨è§£é‡Šæœ€ç»ˆæˆç»©æ—¶ï¼Œæ¯”æ™ºå•†é‡è¦ä¸¤å€ã€‚ Gender Differences æ€§åˆ«å·®å¼‚ å¥³å­©: é˜…è¯»ã€å†™ä½œå’Œè¯­è¨€ä½¿ç”¨æ–¹é¢æ›´å¥½ã€‚ ç”·å­©: æ•°å­¦ç´ å…»ã€è§†è§‰å’Œç©ºé—´åŠŸèƒ½æ–¹é¢é¢†å…ˆã€‚ Adolescents in the Workplace é’å°‘å¹´åœ¨å·¥ä½œåœºæ‰€Employment å°±ä¸š Prevalence: Vast majority employed at some time during high school. æ™®éæ€§: å¤§å¤šæ•°äººåœ¨é«˜ä¸­æœŸé—´éƒ½æœ‰å°±ä¸šç»å†ã€‚ Paths ä¸¤ç§è·¯å¾„ Accelerated Path: Toward adulthood. Leisurely Transition: Balancing work and school. åŠ é€Ÿè·¯å¾„: èµ°å‘æˆå¹´ã€‚ ä¼‘é—²è¿‡æ¸¡: å¹³è¡¡å·¥ä½œå’Œå­¦ä¹ ã€‚ Positive Effects: More positive effects if working hours are limited and students remain engaged in school activities. ç§¯ææ•ˆæœ: å¦‚æœå·¥ä½œæ—¶é—´æœ‰é™ï¼Œä¸”å­¦ç”Ÿä»ç„¶å‚ä¸å­¦æ ¡æ´»åŠ¨ï¼Œåˆ™æ•ˆæœæ›´ç§¯æã€‚

posts.text: PSY2033 Developmental Psychology Ch14 Phychosocial Development in Emerging and Young Adulthood Personality Development: Four models1. Normative Stage Model è§„èŒƒé˜¶æ®µæ¨¡å‹ Models that argue for a definite sequence of age-related changes in psychosocial development. è¿™äº›æ¨¡å‹è®¤ä¸ºå¿ƒç†ç¤¾ä¼šå‘å±•ä¸­å­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªç¡®å®šçš„å¹´é¾„ç›¸å…³å˜åŒ–åºåˆ—ã€‚ Erikson: Intimacy versus Isolation: Make commitments to others or face a possible sense of isolation and consequent self-absorption. è¾¾æˆå¯¹ä»–äººçš„æ‰¿è¯ºï¼Œå¦åˆ™å¯èƒ½é¢ä¸´å­¤ç«‹æ„Ÿå’Œéšä¹‹è€Œæ¥çš„è‡ªæˆ‘å¸æ”¶ã€‚ Virtue Attained: Love, a mutual devotion between partners who have chosen to share their lives, have children, and help those children achieve their own healthy development. è·å¾—çš„ç¾å¾·ï¼šçˆ±ï¼Œä¸€ç§åœ¨é€‰æ‹©åˆ†äº«ç”Ÿæ´»ã€ç”Ÿè‚²å­å¥³å¹¶å¸®åŠ©è¿™äº›å­©å­å®ç°è‡ªèº«å¥åº·å‘å±•çš„ä¼´ä¾£ä¹‹é—´çš„ç›¸äº’å¥‰çŒ®ã€‚ Life Structure: The underlying pattern of a personâ€™s life at a given time, built on whatever aspects of life the person finds most important. ä¸€ä¸ªäººåœ¨ç‰¹å®šæ—¶é—´çš„ç”Ÿæ´»çš„åŸºç¡€æ¨¡å¼ï¼ŒåŸºäºä¸ªäººè®¤ä¸ºæœ€é‡è¦çš„ç”Ÿæ´»æ–¹é¢ã€‚ Dream: Oneâ€™s hopes about what one wishes to achieve in the future, part of the entry phase of young adulthood. æ¢¦æƒ³ï¼šä¸€ä¸ªäººå¯¹æœªæ¥å¸Œæœ›å®ç°çš„ç›®æ ‡ï¼Œæ˜¯é’å¹´æœŸå…¥é—¨é˜¶æ®µçš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚ Emerging Adulthood: Period between the ages of 18-25. Shifting cultural forces; delayed onset of full adulthood. æ–‡åŒ–åŠ›é‡çš„è½¬å˜ï¼›æˆå¹´æœŸçš„å»¶è¿Ÿå¼€å§‹ã€‚ Increase in the amount of education needed for a good career. è‰¯å¥½èŒä¸šæ‰€éœ€æ•™è‚²æ°´å¹³çš„æé«˜ã€‚ Frequency of cohabitation without marriage. æœªå©šåŒå±…çš„é¢‘ç‡ã€‚ Continued identity exploration. æŒç»­çš„èº«ä»½æ¢ç´¢ã€‚ Insecurity, instability, self-focus. ä¸å®‰å…¨ã€ä¸ç¨³å®šã€ä»¥è‡ªæˆ‘ä¸ºä¸­å¿ƒã€‚ Normative Studies of Women: Women may face different psychological and environmental constraints in forming life structures than men do. å¥³æ€§åœ¨å½¢æˆç”Ÿæ´»ç»“æ„æ—¶å¯èƒ½é¢ä¸´ä¸ç”·æ€§ä¸åŒçš„å¿ƒç†å’Œç¯å¢ƒé™åˆ¶ã€‚ Womenâ€™s transitions tend to take longer. å¥³æ€§çš„è½¬å˜å¾€å¾€éœ€è¦æ›´é•¿æ—¶é—´ã€‚ Between age 27-43, women (as opposed to 17-33 for men) develop more self-discipline, commitment, independence, and confidence. åœ¨27-43å²ä¹‹é—´ï¼Œå¥³æ€§ï¼ˆç›¸æ¯”ç”·æ€§çš„17-33å²ï¼‰å‘å±•å‡ºæ›´å¤šçš„è‡ªå¾‹ã€æ‰¿è¯ºã€ç‹¬ç«‹å’Œè‡ªä¿¡ã€‚ 2. Timing-of-Events Model äº‹ä»¶æ—¶æœºæ¨¡å‹ A model that describes adult psychosocial development as a response to the expected or unexpected occurrence and timing of important life events. ä¸€ç§å°†æˆå¹´å¿ƒç†ç¤¾ä¼šå‘å±•æè¿°ä¸ºå¯¹é‡è¦ç”Ÿæ´»äº‹ä»¶é¢„æœŸæˆ–éé¢„æœŸå‘ç”ŸåŠå…¶æ—¶æœºçš„å“åº”çš„æ¨¡å‹ã€‚ Social Clock: A set of cultural norms or expectations for the times of life when important events, such as marriage, parenthood, entry into work, and retirement, should occur. ç¤¾ä¼šæ—¶é’Ÿï¼šä¸€ç»„å…³äºé‡è¦äº‹ä»¶ï¼ˆå¦‚ç»“å©šã€è‚²å„¿ã€è¿›å…¥èŒåœºå’Œé€€ä¼‘ï¼‰åº”ä½•æ—¶å‘ç”Ÿçš„æ–‡åŒ–è§„èŒƒæˆ–æœŸæœ›ã€‚ 3. Traits Model ç‰¹è´¨æ¨¡å‹ Models that focus on mental, emotional, temperamental, and behavioral traits, or attributes. è¿™äº›æ¨¡å‹å…³æ³¨å¿ƒç†ã€æƒ…ç»ªã€æ°”è´¨å’Œè¡Œä¸ºç‰¹è´¨æˆ–å±æ€§ã€‚ Big Five Personality Traits: Neuroticism: The tendency to experience emotional instability: anxiety, hostility, depression, self-consciousness, impulsiveness, and vulnerability very easily. Extraversion: The tendency to seek stimulation and enjoy the company of other people. Agreeableness: The tendency to be trusting and compassionate rather than distrustful of and antagonistic towards others. Conscientiousness: The tendency to show self-discipline, to be reliable, and to strive for competence and achievement. Openness to Experience: The tendency to enjoy new experiences and new ideas. posts.title: PSY2043 Ch04 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch04 Sensory Process senses Include vision, hearing, smell, taste, and touch Sensatation vs Perception At psychological level å¿ƒç†å­¦å±‚é¢ Sensatations are raw experiences of stimuli not yet imbued with meaning åŸå§‹åˆºæ¿€ Perception involves the integration and meaningful interpretation of these raw sensory experiences è§£é‡Šä¿¡æ¯ At biological level ç”Ÿç‰©å­¦å±‚é¢ Sensory processes involve the sense organs and the neural pathways that emanate from them Perceptual processes involve higher levels of the cortex Intended Learning Outcomes Explain how sensations are experienced on a psychological and a biological level. Psychological â€“ raw experiences of stimuli not yet imbued with meaning Biological â€“ sense organs and the neural pathways Describe the role of sensitivity, intensity, and magnitude of above threshold stimuli for the different sensory modalities. å²è’‚æ–‡æ–¯å®šå¾‹ Stevensâ€™ law ï¼ˆå¹‚å‡½æ•°å®šå¾‹ï¼‰ çŸ¥è§‰çš„å¿ƒç†å¼ºåº¦ï¼ˆ$\Psi$ï¼‰ä¸ºç‰©ç†å¼ºåº¦ï¼ˆ$\Phi$ï¼‰çš„æŒ‡æ•°å‡½æ•° $\Psi = \Phi^{r}$ Understand that signals are present in background noise and that they may be missed when present (misses) and may be detected when not present (false alarms). AIDS epidemic. posts.title: PSY2043 Ch03 Lecture Notes
posts.text: PSY2043 Introduction to Psychology Ch03 Psychological Development Intended Learning Outcomes Understand how heredity and environment interact to determine human development. Be able to define the concept of maturation and show how it relates to this interaction. Genetically determined characteristics are expressed through the process of maturation. The environment affects the rate at which children acquire the skills, not the ultimate skill level Maturation â€“ an innately determined sequence of growth and change that is relatively independent of external events å…ˆå¤©å†³å®šçš„æˆé•¿å’Œå˜åŒ–çš„é¡ºåºï¼Œç›¸å¯¹ç‹¬ç«‹äºå¤–éƒ¨äº‹ä»¶ Be familiar with what psychologists mean by developmental stages and by the related concepts of critical and sensitive periods. Stages of development Behavior at a given stage is organised around a coherent set of characteristics Behavior at each stage is qualitatively different from that at earlier or later stages States that all children go through the same stages in the same order (many psychologists disagree) Environmental factors may affect speed of progress through, but not the order of, stages Critical periods â€“ crucial time periods in a personâ€™s life when specific events occur if development is to proceed normally Sensitive periods â€“ periods that are optimal for a particular kind of development Be able to describe the capacities of the newborn and the procedures used to assess these capacities. Capacities Vision â€“ poor, cannot see as well as an adult until about age 2. å³ä½¿æ–°ç”Ÿå„¿ä¹Ÿä¼šæ³¨æ„åˆ°å£°éŸ³ï¼Œä»–ä»¬ä¼¼ä¹å¤©ç”Ÿå…·æœ‰å·²è°ƒæ•´åˆ°å°†å¸®åŠ©ä»–ä»¬å­¦ä¹ è¯­è¨€çš„äººç±»è¯­éŸ³ç‰¹æ€§çš„æ„ŸçŸ¥æœºåˆ¶ Infants can discriminate between different tastes and odors shortly after birth. They seem to show a preference for the taste and odor of breast milk. Infants can learn from the moment they are born and show good memories by three months of age Procedures Know the sequence of Piagetâ€˜s stages of cognitive development and some difficulties with Piagetâ€™s theory and with alternative views. Be able to describe Kohlbergâ€™s work on moral reasoning and its three levels. Piagetâ€™s theory Stages Sensorimotor (0-2) Preoperational (2-7) Concrete operational (7-11) Formal operational (11+) Difficulties Understimate childrenâ€™s abilities Alternatives Information-processing approaches Knowledge-acquistion approaches Sociocultural approaches Kohlberg Piaget believed childrenâ€™s understanding of moral rules developed along with cognitive abilities Kohlberg extended Piagetâ€™s work to include adolescence and adulthood and arrived at six developmental stages of moral judgment, grouped into three levels Level 1 â€“ Preconventional morality Level 2 â€“ Conventional morality Level 3 â€“ Postconventional morality Be familiar with characteristics of personality development and early social behavior. Be familiar with some aspects of the physiology of puberty and with psychological effects of this period on various dimensions of the adolescent.
